verses.latin: Proverbia Salomonis filii David, regis Israël:
verses.english: These are the proverbs of Solomon, the son of David, king of Israel:

verses.latin: Ad sciendam sapientiam et disciplinam:
verses.english: Their purpose is to teach wisdom and discipline;

verses.latin: Ad intelligenda verba prudentiæ:
verses.english: To help you understand the words of the wise;

verses.latin: Ad suscipiendam eruditionem doctrinæ, justitiam, et judicium, et æquitatem:
verses.english: To help you receive training in doctrine, justice, judgment, and equity;

verses.latin: Ut detur parvulis astutia, adulescenti scientia et intellectus.
verses.english: So that children may be prudent, and the young may have knowledge and understanding.

verses.latin: Audiet sapiens, et sapientior erit: et intelligens, gubernacula possidebit.
verses.english: The wise will listen, and become wiser; and those who understand will guide themselves well.

verses.latin: Incipiat timor Domini scientiæ: sapientiam atque doctrinam stulti despiciunt.
verses.english: The fear of God is the beginning of knowledge, but fools despise wisdom and doctrine.

verses.latin: Audi, fili mi, disciplinam patris tui, et ne dimittas legem matris tuæ:
verses.english: Listen, my son, to the discipline of your father, and don't abandon the law of your mother:

verses.latin: Ut addatur gratia capiti tuo, et torques collo tuo.
verses.english: For these teachings will be a graceful ornament for your head, and a chain for your neck.

verses.latin: Fili mi, si te lactaverint peccatores, ne acquiescas eis.
verses.english: My son, if sinners entice you, do not consent.

verses.latin: Si dixerint: Veni nobiscum, insidiemur sanguini, abscondamus tendiculas contra innocentem frustra:
verses.english: If they say, “Come with us, let us lay in wait for blood, let us hide snares against the innocent without cause:

verses.latin: Deglutiamus eum sicut infernus viventem, et justum quasi descendentem in lacum:
verses.english: Let us swallow him up alive like hell, and the just as if he were going down into a pit:

verses.latin: Omnem pretiosam substantiam reperiemus: implebimus domos nostras spoliis:
verses.english: We shall find all precious substance, we will fill our houses with spoils:

verses.latin: Sortem mittat nobiscum, et marsupium sit commune omnibus nobis.
verses.english: Cast in your lot among us, and let us all have one purse:

verses.latin: Fili mi, ne ambules cum eis; prohibe pedem tuum a semitis eorum:
verses.english: My son, do not walk with them, restrain your foot from their paths:

verses.latin: Pedes enim illorum ad malum currunt, et festinant ut effundant sanguinem.
verses.english: For their feet run to evil, and they make haste to shed blood.

verses.latin: Frustra autem jacitur rete ante oculos pennatorum.
verses.english: But in vain the net is spread before the eyes of those who have wings.

verses.latin: Ipsi enim contra sanguinem suum insidiantur, et moliuntur fraudes animabus suis.
verses.english: For they lie in wait against their own blood, and practice deceits against their own souls.

verses.latin: Sic itinera omnis avari: animas possessorum rapiunt.
verses.english: So are the ways of everyone who is greedy for gain: they take away the souls of their possessors.

verses.latin: Sapientia foris prædicat: in plateis dat vocem suam:
verses.english: Wisdom cries out in the streets, she utters her voice in the squares:

verses.latin: In capite turbarum clamitat: in introitu portarum loquitur.
verses.english: At the head of crowds she cries out, in the entrance of the gates she speaks:

verses.latin: Usquequo, parvuli, diligetis infantiam vestram, et stulti, ea quæ vobis noceant, cupietis?
verses.english: How long, O little ones, will you love childhood, and you fools desire what is hurtful to you?

verses.latin: Convertimini ad correptionem meam: ecce, ego effundam vobis spiritum meum, et ostendam vobis verba mea.
verses.english: Turn to my reproof; behold, I will pour out my spirit to you, and I will show you my words.

verses.latin: Quia vocavi, et renuistis: extendi manum meam, et non fuit qui audiret:
verses.english: Because I have called, and you refused: I have stretched out my hand, and there was no one who would listen:

verses.latin: Sed pro nihilo habuistis omne consilium meum, et correptiones meas neglexistis:
verses.english: But you have treated all my counsel as nothing, and have neglected my reproofs:

verses.latin: Ego quoque in interitu vestro ridebo: et subsannabo, cum vobis quod timuistis, advenerit.
verses.english: I also will laugh at your destruction: and I will mock when what you feared comes upon you,

verses.latin: Cum irruerit repentina calamitas, et contritio quasi tempestas ingruerit: cum tribulatio et angustia venerit.
verses.english: When sudden calamity falls upon you, and destruction comes like a storm: when tribulation and anguish come upon you.

verses.latin: Tunc invocabunt me, et non exaudiam: mane consurgent, et non invenient me:
verses.english: Then they will call upon me, and I will not hear: they will rise early in the morning, and they will not find me:

verses.latin: Eo quod spreverint scientiam, et timorem Domini non elegerint:
verses.english: Because they have despised knowledge, and have not chosen the fear of God:

verses.latin: Nec voluerunt consilium meum, et correptiones meas contempserunt:
verses.english: Nor have they willed my counsel, and have scorned my reproofs:

verses.latin: Comedent igitur de fructu viæ suæ, et consiliis suis saturabuntur.
verses.english: Therefore they shall eat of the fruit of their own way, and they shall be filled with their own devices.

verses.latin: Recessio parvulorum interficiet eos, et prosperitas stultorum illudet illos.
verses.english: The turning away of the little ones will kill them, and the prosperity of fools will deceive them.

verses.latin: Qui autem crediderit mihi, requiescet in spe, et abundabit timore.
verses.english: But whoever believes in me, shall rest in hope, and shall abound with the fear of God.

verses.latin: Fili mi, si susceperis sermones meos, et mandata mea reposueris tecum,
verses.english: My son, if you receive my words and treasure my precepts,

verses.latin: ut audiat sapientiam auris tua, inclina cor tuum ad prudentiam:
verses.english: Then you will train your heart to understand, and turn your ear to wisdom.

verses.latin: si enim clamaveris ad sapientiam, et inclinaveris cor tuum ad prudentiam:
verses.english: Yes, if you ask to understand, and if you direct your heart to discern wisdom—

verses.latin: si quaesieris eam quasi pecuniam, et quasi thesauros effoderis eam:
verses.english: If you seek her like silver, and search for her like a treasure—

verses.latin: tunc intelliges timorem Domini, et scientiam Dei invenies.
verses.english: Then you will understand the fear of the Lord, and you will find the knowledge of God.

verses.latin: Quia Dominus dat sapientiam, et de ore ejus prudentia et intellectus:
verses.english: For the Lord gives wisdom, and from His mouth comes understanding and insight.

verses.latin: qui custodit thesaurum justorum. Protector est ambulantium in simplicitate,
verses.english: He treasures the honest. He protects the way of those who live blamelessly,

verses.latin: custodiens semitas judicii, et vias sanctorum conservat.
verses.english: preserving the paths of justice, and safeguarding the ways of the saints.

verses.latin: Tunc intelliges justitiam, et judicium, et aequitatem, et omnem viam bonam.
verses.english: Then you will understand justice and judgment and fairness, and every good path.

verses.latin: Si enim intraverit sapientia cor tuum, et scientia animae tuae placuerit,
verses.english: If wisdom enters your heart, and knowledge delights your soul,

verses.latin: consilium custodiet te, et prudentia conservabit te:
verses.english: Then counsel will protect you, and prudence will preserve you:

verses.latin: ut eruaris a via mala, et ab homine qui perversa loquitur:
verses.english: to rescue you from the evil way, and from the man who speaks perverse things:

verses.latin: qui derelinquunt viam rectam, et gradiuntur per vias tenebrosas:
verses.english: those who abandon the straight path, and walk the dark paths:

verses.latin: qui laetantur cum male fecerint, et exultant in rebus pessimis:
verses.english: who rejoice when they do evil, and exult in the worst things:

verses.latin: quorum viae perversae sunt, et gressus eorum pravi.
verses.english: whose paths are crooked, and whose steps are twisted.

verses.latin: Ut eruaris a muliere extranea, et ab aliena quae verba sua dulcificat,
verses.english: And to deliver you from a strange woman, and from the foreigner who makes her words sweet:

verses.latin: quae derelinquit virum principatum suum, et oblita est foederis Dei sui.
verses.english: who abandons the husband of her youth and has forgotten the covenant of her God.

verses.latin: Prope enim ad mortem domus illius, et ad infernum semitae ejus.
verses.english: For her house is near death, and her paths lead to the underworld.

verses.latin: Omnes qui ingrediuntur ad eam, non revertentur, neque sustentabunt semitas rectas.
verses.english: All who enter her do not return, and do not sustain the right paths.

verses.latin: Profecto justus ambulabit in simplicitate sua: qui graditur in via aequa, gressus ejus manifesti erunt.
verses.english: So that a just man walks in his integrity: his steps are clear for one who walks the right way.

verses.latin: Quia recti habitabunt terram, et perfecti permanebunt in ea.
verses.english: For the upright shall inhabit the land, and the perfect will remain in it.

verses.latin: Impii vero de terra perdentur: et qui in ea gerunt iniquitatem, auferentur.
verses.english: But the wicked will be cut off from the earth: and those who deal unjustly will be removed from it.

verses.latin: Fili mi, legem meam ne obliviscaris, et praecepta mea custodiat cor tuum:
verses.english: My son, don't forget my teachings, and let your heart guard my commandments.

verses.latin: quia longitudinem dierum, et annos vitae, et pacem, adicient tibi.
verses.english: They will add to you long life, many years, and peace.

verses.latin: Misericordiam et veritatem ne deseras, sed ligato ea in gutture tuo, et scribe ea in tabulis cordis tui:
verses.english: Never forsake kindness and truth, but tie them around your neck, and write them on the tablets of your heart.

verses.latin: et invenies gratiam et industriam bonam in conspectu Dei et hominum.
verses.english: Then you will find favor and good understanding in the sight of God and of men.

verses.latin: Fiduciam habe in Domino ex toto corde tuo, et ne innitaris prudentiae tuae.
verses.english: Trust in the Lord with all your heart, and do not rely on your own understanding.

verses.latin: In omnibus viis tuis cogita de eo, et ipse diriget gressus tuos.
verses.english: In all your ways, give thought to Him, and He will direct your steps.

verses.latin: Ne sis sapiens in oculis tuis; time Dominum, et recede a malo.
verses.english: Don’t think you are wise in your own eyes; fear the Lord, and turn away from evil.

verses.latin: Hoc erit sanitati umbilico tuo, et irrigatio ossium tuorum.
verses.english: This will be health for your navel, and nourishment for your bones.

verses.latin: Honora Dominum de substantia tua, et de primitiis frugum tuarum da ei.
verses.english: Honor the Lord with your possessions, and give Him the first fruits of your crops.

verses.latin: Et implebuntur horrea tua saturitate, et vino torcularia tua redundabunt.
verses.english: Then your barns will be filled to overflowing, and your vats will overflow with wine.

verses.latin: Disciplinam Domini, fili mi, ne abjicias, nec fastidias cum ab eo corriperis:
verses.english: My son, do not reject the Lord’s discipline, nor be disgusted when you are corrected by Him:

verses.latin: quem enim diligit Dominus, corripit, et quasi pater in filio complacet sibi.
verses.english: because the Lord corrects the one He loves, as a father corrects the son in whom he delights.

verses.latin: Beatus homo qui invenit sapientiam, et qui affluit prudentia:
verses.english: Happy is the man who finds wisdom, and the man who overflows with understanding:

verses.latin: melior est enim illa negotiatio argenti, et fructus ejus melior auro pretioso.
verses.english: For her profit is better than the profit of silver, and her revenue is better than fine gold.

verses.latin: Preciosior est cunctis gemmis, et omnia quae desiderantur huic non valent comparari.
verses.english: She is more precious than all gems, and nothing you desire can compare to her.

verses.latin: Longitudo dierum in dextera ejus, et in sinistra illius gloria.
verses.english: Long life is in her right hand, and in her left hand are riches and honor.

verses.latin: Viae ejus viae pulchrae, et omnes semitae illius pacem.
verses.english: Her ways are pleasant ways, and all her paths are peace.

verses.latin: Lignum vitae est his qui apprehenderint eam, et qui possederit eam beatus est.
verses.english: She is a tree of life to those who grasp her, and happy is the one who holds her fast.

verses.latin: Dominus sapientia fundavit terram, et prudentia stabilivit caelos.
verses.english: The Lord by wisdom founded the earth, and by understanding He established the heavens.

verses.latin: Scientia illius erumpuerunt abyssi, et nubes rore guttant.
verses.english: By His knowledge the depths were broken up, and the clouds drop down the dew.

verses.latin: Fili mi, ne effluant haec ab oculis tuis: custodi legem atque consilium.
verses.english: My son, let these things not depart from your sight: keep sound wisdom and discretion.

verses.latin: Et erunt vita animae tuae, et gratia collo tuo.
verses.english: So they will be life for your soul and grace for your neck.

verses.latin: Tunc ambulabis fiducialiter in via tua, et pes tuus non offendet.
verses.english: Then you will go your way confidently, and your foot will not stumble.

verses.latin: Si dormieris, non timebis; dormies, et suavis erit somnus tuus.
verses.english: If you lie down, you will not be afraid; when you sleep, your sleep will be sweet.

verses.latin: Noli timere a timore repentino, et irruptionem impiorum cum venerit.
verses.english: Do not be afraid of sudden fear, nor of the ruin of the wicked when it comes.

verses.latin: Quoniam Dominus erit in spe tua, et custodiet pedem tuum, ne capiaris.
verses.english: For the Lord will be your confidence, and will keep your foot from being caught.

verses.latin: Noli prohibere a puero beneficium, cum potestas tibi fuerit faciendi bonum.
verses.english: Do not withhold good from those to whom it is due, when it is in your power to do it.

verses.latin: Ne dicas amico tuo: Vade, et reverteris, et cras dabo tibi, cum statim possis dare.
verses.english: Do not say to your neighbor, “Go, and come back, and tomorrow I will give it,” when you have it with you.

verses.latin: Ne mediteris malum contra amicum tuum, cum ille in te habeat fiduciam.
verses.english: Do not plan evil against your neighbor, when he trusts in you.

verses.latin: Ne contendas frustra contra hominem, qui tibi nihil mali fecit.
verses.english: Do not quarrel with a man without cause, if he has done you no harm.

verses.latin: Ne aemuleris hominem iniquum, nec imiteris vias ejus:
verses.english: Do not envy the man of violence, nor choose any of his ways:

verses.latin: quia abominatio Domini est omnis vir perversus, et cum probos non communicabit.
verses.english: because the perverse man is an abomination to the Lord, but He is intimate with the upright.

verses.latin: Domini, et maledictio impii demolietur.
verses.english: The Lord’s curse is on the house of the wicked, but He blesses the dwelling of the just.

verses.latin: Vere impios irridebit, et iustis tribuet gratiam.
verses.english: Truly, He mocks at the scornful, but gives grace to the humble.

verses.latin: Gloriam sapientes possidebunt, stulti vero contumeliam tolent.
verses.english: The wise will inherit glory, but fools will receive disgrace.

verses.latin: Audite, filii, doctrinam patris, et attendite ut cognoscatis prudentiam.
verses.english: Listen, sons, to the teachings of your father, and pay attention so you may understand wisdom.

verses.latin: Dabo enim vobis doctrinam bonam: ne derelinquatis legem meam.
verses.english: I will give you good teaching: don't abandon my law.

verses.latin: Eram enim et ego filius patris mei, tener et unigenitus in oculis matris meae.
verses.english: I was a son of my father, gentle and beloved in the eyes of my mother.

verses.latin: Et docebat me, et dicebat mihi: Suscipe verba mea in corde tuo, custodi praecepta mea, et vive.
verses.english: And he taught me, and said to me: “Keep my words in your heart, guard my precepts, and live by them.”

verses.latin: Posside sapientiam, posside prudentiam: ne obliviscaris, neque declines a verbis oris mei.
verses.english: Get wisdom, get understanding: don't forget, and don't turn away from the words of my mouth.

verses.latin: Ne dimittas eam, et custodiet te; dilige eam, et conservabit te.
verses.english: Don't abandon her, and she will guard you; love her, and she will protect you.

verses.latin: Principium sapientiæ, posside sapientiam, et in omni possessione tua acquire prudentiam.
verses.english: The beginning of wisdom is, get wisdom, and with all your possessions, acquire understanding.

verses.latin: Amplectere eam, et exaltabit te: glorificaberis ab ea, cum eam fueris amplexus.
verses.english: Embrace her, and she will exalt you; you will be glorified by her, when you have embraced her.

verses.latin: Dabit capiti tuo augmentum gratiæ, et gloria coronabit te.
verses.english: She will give your head the grace of growth, and she will crown you with glory.

verses.latin: Audi, fili mi, et suscipe verba mea, et multiplicabuntur tibi anni vitæ.
verses.english: Listen, my son, and accept my words, and the years of your life will multiply for you.

verses.latin: Viam sapientiæ monstrabo tibi, et ducam te per vestigia æquitatis:
verses.english: I will show you the path of wisdom, and I will lead you in the footsteps of righteousness:

verses.latin: quæ cum ingressus fueris, non coarctabuntur gressus tui; et cum cucurreris, non habebis tristitiam.
verses.english: when you enter it, your steps will not be constricted; and when you run, you will not have sadness.

verses.latin: Cape disciplinam, ne dimittas eam; custodi illam, quia ipsa est vita tua.
verses.english: Take discipline, do not abandon it; guard it, because it is your life.

verses.latin: Ne ingrediaris semitam impiorum, nec calces viam peccatorum.
verses.english: Don't enter the path of the wicked, nor tread the way of sinners.

verses.latin: Devita eam, et noli transire per illam; declina, et recede ab ea.
verses.english: Avoid it, and do not pass through it; turn away, and depart from it.

verses.latin: Non enim dormiunt, nisi malum fecerint: et rapitur somnus eorum, nisi subplantarint.
verses.english: For they do not sleep unless they have done evil: and their sleep is taken away unless they have tripped someone.

verses.latin: Comedunt enim panem impietatis, et vinum iniquitatis bibunt.
verses.english: For they eat the bread of ungodliness, and they drink the wine of iniquity.

verses.latin: Justorum autem, quasi lux splendescit, et iustificabitur usque ad perfectam diem.
verses.english: But the path of the just is like light traveling through space, and it will be made just until the perfect day.

verses.latin: Via impiorum tenebrosa: nesciunt ubi corruant.
verses.english: The way of the wicked is dark: they do not know where they fall.

verses.latin: Fili mi, attendite sermonibus meis: et ad eloquia mea inclina aurem tuam.
verses.english: My son, pay attention to my words: and incline your ear to my sayings.

verses.latin: Ne recedant ab oculis tuis: custodi illa in medio cordis tui.
verses.english: Let them not depart from your eyes: guard them in the middle of your heart.

verses.latin: Vita sunt enim illi his qui inveniunt ea: et universæ carni sanitas.
verses.english: For they are life to those who find them: and health to all flesh.

verses.latin: Omni custodia serva cor tuum: quia ex ipso vitæ prodeunt.
verses.english: Keep watch over your heart with every care: because from it, the ways of life come forth.

verses.latin: Amove a te os pravum, et labia mendacia longe facito a te.
verses.english: Remove from you a perverse mouth, and put lying lips far from you.

verses.latin: Oculi tui recta videant, et palpebræ tuæ gressus tuos dirigant.
verses.english: Let your eyes look straight ahead, and let your eyelids direct your steps.

verses.latin: Dirige gressus tuos, et omnes vias tuas firma.
verses.english: Direct your steps, and make all your ways firm.

verses.latin: Ne declinet ad dexteram, neque ad sinistram: averte pedem tuum a malo.
verses.english: Do not turn to the right or to the left: turn your foot away from evil.

verses.latin: Fili mi, attende sapientiæ meæ: ad prudentiam meam inclina aurem tuam.
verses.english: My son, pay attention to my wisdom. Give ear to my understanding.

verses.latin: Ut custodias consilium, et scientiam labiorum servabis.
verses.english: Keep discretion, and your lips will guard knowledge.

verses.latin: Noli desiderare mulierem alienam, neque ambias intra limen ejus.
verses.english: Don't long for a woman who isn't your wife, and don't wander around her house.

verses.latin: Quia favus stillans labia meretricis, et nitidius oleo guttur ejus.
verses.english: For the lips of a harlot are like a dripping honeycomb, and her throat is smoother than oil.

verses.latin: Novissima quidem amara quasi absinthium, et acuta quasi gladius biceps.
verses.english: But in the end, she is as bitter as wormwood, and sharp as a two-edged sword.

verses.latin: Pedes ejus descendunt in mortem, et gressus ejus usque ad inferos.
verses.english: Her feet go down to death, and her steps lead straight to the grave.

verses.latin: Semitas vitæ non calcat: vagi sunt gressus ejus, et ignoti.
verses.english: She doesn't walk the paths of life. Her steps are always wandering, and you can't predict where she will go.

verses.latin: Nunc ergo, fili, audi me, et ne recedas a verbis oris mei.
verses.english: Now, my son, listen to me and don't turn away from the words I am saying.

verses.latin: Longe fac ab ea viam tuam, et ne adpropinques foribus domus ejus:
verses.english: Keep your way far from her, and don't go near the door of her house.

verses.latin: ne fortè des alienis honorem tuum, et annos tuos crudelibus:
verses.english: Lest you should give your honor to others, and your years to those who are cruel.

verses.latin: ne impleantur extranei viribus tuis, et labores tui in domo aliena;
verses.english: Lest strangers be filled with your strength, and your labors in the house of someone else,

verses.latin: et paeniteas in novissimo, quando consumpseris carnem tuam et corpus tuum, et dicas:
verses.english: And in the end you will regret it, when you've ruined your flesh and your body, and say:

verses.latin: Quomodo odivi disciplinam, et in cordibus meis fastidivit correptio!
verses.english: “How I hated discipline, and my heart scorned rebuke!

verses.latin: Et non audivi vocem docentium me, neque inclinavi aurem meam præbentibus mihi.
verses.english: I didn’t listen to the voice of those who taught me, nor did I pay attention to those who gave me instruction.

verses.latin: Penè fui in omni malo in medio ecclesia et synagogæ.
verses.english: I almost fell into every kind of evil in the middle of the Church and the synagogues.

verses.latin: Bibe aquam de cisterna tua, et de fontibus putei tui.
verses.english: Drink water from your own cistern, and from the springs of your well.

verses.latin: Non effundantur fontes tui foras, sed in plateis divide aquas tuas.
verses.english: Let your springs be poured out outside, but divide your waters into the streets.

verses.latin: Sint tibi soli, et non alienis tecum.
verses.english: Let them be yours alone, and not those of strangers with you.

verses.latin: Sit benedicta fons tua, et laetare cum muliere adolescentiæ tuæ:
verses.english: Let your fountain be blessed, and rejoice with the wife of your youth.

verses.latin: cerva carissima, et gratissima gratia: ubera ejus inebrient te in omni tempore, in amore illius delectare semper.
verses.english: A most beautiful hind, and a graceful deer. Let her breasts satisfy you at all times; always delight in her love.

verses.latin: Quare, fili mi, perderis in muliere aliena, et foveris in sinu alterius?
verses.english: Why, my son, should you be ruined with a woman who isn’t your wife, and be embraced in the bosom of another?

verses.latin: Opera hominis in conspectu Domini, et vias ejus ipse considerat.
verses.english: The works of a man are in the sight of the Lord, and He considers his ways.

verses.latin: Iniquus capiatur in peccatis suis, et in vinculis delictorum suorum detinetur.
verses.english: The wicked are caught in their own sins, and are held fast in the chains of their own offenses.

verses.latin: Fili mi, si spoponderis pro proximo tuo, et obligaveris manum tuam pro altero,
verses.english: My son, if you have agreed to be surety for your neighbor, and have pledged your word for another,

verses.latin: captus es in verbis oris tui, et comprehen-sus es verbis labiorum tuorum,
verses.english: you are ensnared by the words of your mouth, and taken captive by the words of your lips,

verses.latin: fac quod dico, fili mi, et eripe te, quia incidisti in manu proximi tui: propera, et con-trahe te.
verses.english: do what I say, my son, and deliver yourself; because you have fallen into the hands of your neighbor: hasten and withdraw.

verses.latin: Ne da somnum oculis tuis, nec palpebris tuis dormitationem.
verses.english: Give not sleep to your eyes, nor slumber to your eyelids.

verses.latin: Erue te quasi dama de manu, et quasi avis de manu venantis.
verses.english: Be delivered as a roe from the hand, and as a bird from the hand of the fowler.

verses.latin: Vade ad formicam, o piger, et considera vias ejus, et disce sapientiam.
verses.english: Go to the ant, O sluggard, and consider her ways, and learn wisdom.

verses.latin: Quæ cum non habeat ducem, nec præceptorem, nec dominum,
verses.english: Which although she has no guide, nor master, nor lord,

verses.latin: parat in æstate cibum sibi, et congregat in messe quod comedat.
verses.english: provides her food in the summer, and gathers in the harvest what she may eat.

verses.latin: Usquequo piger dormis? quando de somno surgis?
verses.english: How long, you sluggard, will you sleep? When will you arise from your sleep?

verses.latin: Modicum dormies, paululum dormitabis, pauxillum manus conseres ut quiescas:
verses.english: A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to rest:

verses.latin: et veniet quasi viator egestas tua, et paupertas tua quasi vir armatus.
verses.english: and your poverty shall come as a traveler, and your want as an armed man.

verses.latin: Homo iniquus et vir sine lege ambulat in ore perverso.
verses.english: A wicked man, a man without law, walks with a perverse mouth.

verses.latin: Qui corruit oculos suos, et stringens pedes, et nutu digiti indicat.
verses.english: Who winks with his eyes, and presses with his feet, and speaks with his finger.

verses.latin: Perversitates in corde ejus, cogitat in malis omni tempore, et jurgia seminat.
verses.english: Perversities are in his heart, he devises evil at all times, and sows discord.

verses.latin: Propterea subito veniet perditio ejus: repente conteretur, et non habebit ultra medicinam.
verses.english: Therefore his destruction shall come suddenly; he shall be broken suddenly, and shall no longer have a remedy.

verses.latin: Hæc sunt sex quæ odit Dominus, et septimum abominatur anima ejus:
verses.english: These six things the Lord hates, and the seventh his soul hates:

verses.latin: Oculos superbos, linguam mendacem, manus effundentes sanguinem innocentem,
verses.english: Haughty eyes, a lying tongue, hands that shed innocent blood,

verses.latin: cor machinans cogitationes malas, pedes veloces ad currendum in malum,
verses.english: a heart that devises wicked plots, feet swift to run into evil,

verses.latin: proferentem falsa testimonia exprobrantemque fratribus discordias.
verses.english: a false witness that utters lies, and he that sows discord among brothers.

verses.latin: Custodi, fili mi, præcepta patris tui, et ne dimittas legem matris tuæ:
verses.english: Keep, my son, the precepts of your father, and forsake not the law of your mother:

verses.latin: liga ea in corde tuo jugiter, et circumda ea gutturi tuo.
verses.english: Bind them continually in your heart, and put them around your neck.

verses.latin: Cum ambulaveris, gradiantur tecum; cum dormieris, custodiant te; et cum evigilaveris, loquere cum eis.
verses.english: When you walk, let them go with you; when you sleep, let them keep you; and when you wake, speak with them.

verses.latin: Quia mandatum lucerna est, et lex lux, et via vitæ increpatio disciplinæ:
verses.english: Because the commandment is a lamp, and the law a light, and the way of life is the reproof of discipline:

verses.latin: ut custodias te a muliere mala, et a blandimentis linguæ alienæ.
verses.english: That you may keep yourself from the evil woman, and from the flattery of the tongue of the stranger.

verses.latin: Ne concupiscas speciem ejus in corde tuo, neque capiaris in palpebris ejus.
verses.english: Desire not her beauty in your heart, neither be caught with her eyelids.

verses.latin: Sustentatio enim meretricis usque ad buccellam panis est: et mulier aliena animam pretiosam capturat.
verses.english: For a harlot's sustenance is to the morsel of bread: and the strange woman hunts for the precious soul.

verses.latin: Numquid potest quis abscondere ignem in sinu suo, et vestimenta sua non conburentur?
verses.english: Can a man hide fire in his bosom, and his garments not be burned?

verses.latin: Aut quis potest ambulare super prunas, et pedes suos non exurentur?
verses.english: Or who can walk upon hot coals, and his feet not be burned?

verses.latin: Ita qui ingreditur ad uxorem proximi sui: non erit mundus cum tetigerit eam.
verses.english: So is he that goes in to his neighbor's wife; he shall not be clean that touches her.

verses.latin: Non est culpa in furantem cum furatus fuerit: ut impleat animam suam cum esurierit.
verses.english: It is no fault in him that steals when he is hungry, that he may fill his soul.

verses.latin: Quod si inventus fuerit, reddet septuplum, et universa substantiam domus suæ dabit.
verses.english: But if he be found, he shall restore sevenfold, and shall give all the substance of his house.

verses.latin: Qui adulteria committit, insipiens est: qui autem vult perdere animam suam, ipse faciet illud.
verses.english: He that commits adultery is foolish: but he that would destroy his own soul does it.

verses.latin: Contumeliam et ignominiam con-gregat, et plaga ejus non delebitur.
verses.english: He gathers to himself disgrace and infamy, and his shame shall not be blotted out.

verses.latin: Quia zelus viri iracundiam suscitabit, nec parcet in die vindictæ.
verses.english: For the jealousy of a husband provokes wrath: nor will he spare in the day of revenge.

verses.latin: Nec cujusquam preces suscipiet: nec propitius erit pro peccato.
verses.english: Nor will he accept any man's prayers, nor will he be appeased by any amount of compensation.

verses.latin: Fili mi, custodi sermones meos, et praecepta mea conserva apud te.
verses.english: My son, always remember and guard what I teach you. Always keep in your heart the wisdom I give you.

verses.latin: Serva mandata mea, et vives: et legem meam quasi pupillam oculi tui.
verses.english: Keep my commands, and you will live. Treasure my law like the pupil of your eye.

verses.latin: Liga eam in digitos tuos: scribe eam in tabulis cordis tui.
verses.english: Tie my wisdom to your fingers to remind you. Write it on the tablets of your heart.

verses.latin: Dic sapientiae: Soror mea es: et prudentiam voca amicam tuam:
verses.english: Say to wisdom: “You are my sister.” Call prudence your closest friend:

verses.latin: ut custodiant te a muliere extranea, et ab aliena, quae verba sua dulcia facit.
verses.english: So that they will guard you against a strange woman. Against the one who flatters with her words.

verses.latin: De fenestra enim domus meae per cancellos prospexi,
verses.english: Once I looked out the window of my house. I peered through the lattice,

verses.latin: et vidi parvulos imprudentes: et consideravi inter filios adulescentem, qui indigebat corde:
verses.english: And I saw some naive young men. I noticed a young man with no common sense among them.

verses.latin: transiens per viam juxta angulum, et gradiebatur prope viam domus illius,
verses.english: He was going down the street near her corner. He was walking near the door of her house,

verses.latin: in via juxta domum illius, in crepusculo, et in tenebris noctis,
verses.english: in the twilight, as it was getting dark, in the middle of the night,

verses.latin: ecce occurrit ei mulier in habitu meretricis, parata ad decipiendum corda stultorum:
verses.english: Suddenly, a woman came to meet him. She was dressed like a prostitute, ready to deceive the hearts of fools.

verses.latin: tumultuosa et contumax, et in domo sua non quiescebant pedes ejus:
verses.english: She was loud and defiant. Her feet never stayed in one place.

verses.latin: nunc foris, nunc in plateis, nunc juxta angulos, et in insidiis prope viam.
verses.english: She was now in the streets, now in the squares, now near every corner, lurking near the road.

verses.latin: Apprehensa ergo eum osculata est: et procaci vultu, ait ad eum:
verses.english: She grabbed him and kissed him. She then said to him with a brazen face:

verses.latin: Victimas pro salute debui: hodie solvi vota mea.
verses.english: “I had to offer sacrifices for my safety. Today, I have paid my vows.

verses.latin: Ideo egressa sum obviam tibi, desiderans te, et inveniens te.
verses.english: So I came out to meet you. I wanted you, and I found you!

verses.latin: Vestiui lectum meum tapetibus, funibus ex Aegypto.
verses.english: I have spread my bed with tapestries, with fine linens from Egypt.

verses.latin: Aspergi lectum meum myrrha, et aloe, et cinnamomo.
verses.english: I have perfumed my bed with myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon.

verses.latin: Veni, et inebriemur uberibus, et fruamur concubitu, usque mane: nemo enim vir meus domi est:
verses.english: Come, let's drink our fill of love, and enjoy each other's company until morning. My husband isn’t home,

verses.latin: abiit in peregrinationem longam.
verses.english: He has gone on a long journey.

verses.latin: Fasciculum pecuniae tulit secum: in die festo redibit in domum suam.
verses.english: He took a bag of money with him. He will return home on the appointed day.”

verses.latin: Occurrit ei multis sermonibus, et illexit eum blanditiis labiorum suorum.
verses.english: With her seductive words, she persuaded him. She enticed him with her flattering lips.

verses.latin: Statimque sequitur eam quasi bos ducitur ad victimam, et quasi agnus lasciviens, et ignorans quod ad vincula stultus properat:
verses.english: Immediately he followed her like an ox to the slaughter, like a fool going to be punished, not knowing that he was going to be punished,

verses.latin: donec transfigat sagitta jecur ejus: velut avis festinat ad laqueum, ignorans quod de anima sua agitur.
verses.english: until an arrow pierces his liver. Like a bird darting into a snare, unaware that it’s a matter of life and death.

verses.latin: Nunc ergo fili mi, audi me, et attende verbis oris mei.
verses.english: Now, my son, listen to me and pay attention to the words of my mouth.

verses.latin: Ne avertatur in vias illius cor tuum, neque erres in semitis ejus.
verses.english: Do not let your heart turn to her ways, and do not stray on her paths.

verses.latin: Multi enim vulnerati sunt, et interfecti ab ea: et fortissimi qui interfecti sunt ab ea.
verses.english: Because she has caused many to be wounded and killed. She has killed many of the strongest men.

verses.latin: Viae inferi domus ejus, gradientes ad eam revertuntur usque ad infernum.
verses.english: Her house is the way to the grave; it descends to the chambers of death.

verses.latin: Nonne sapientia clamat, et prudentia emittit vocem suam?
verses.english: Doesn't wisdom cry out? Doesn't careful thought raise its voice?

verses.latin: In summis locis super viam, in mediis semitis stans,
verses.english: Wisdom stands in the highest places, in the middle of the public roads,

verses.latin: juxta portas urbis, in ipsis foribus loquitur, dicens:
verses.english: near the city gates, and it is the first thing people hear.

verses.latin: O viri, ad vos clamito, et vox mea ad filios hominum.
verses.english: “I call out to you, men. My voice is for all people.

verses.latin: Intelligite, imprudentes, corda, et vos, stulti, mente comprehendite.
verses.english: You who are foolish, learn common sense. You who are simple, apply your minds.

verses.latin: Audite, quoniam de magnis loquar, et aperiam labia mea ut recta praedicem.
verses.english: Listen, because I will speak of great things. I will open my lips to say what is right.

verses.latin: Veritas meditabitur guttur meum, et labia mea detestabuntur impium.
verses.english: My mouth will proclaim truth. My lips hate wicked speech.

verses.latin: Justa sunt cuncta verba mea; nihil est in eis pravum, neque perversum.
verses.english: All my words are just. There is nothing twisted or wrong in them.

verses.latin: Omnia recta sunt intelligentibus, et convenientia invenientibus scientiam.
verses.english: Everything is clear to those who understand, and truth will come to those who know.

verses.latin: Suscipite disciplinam meam, et non pecuniam; et doctrinam magis quam aurum pretiosissimum.
verses.english: Accept my instruction, not money; and knowledge more than the purest gold.

verses.latin: Melior est enim sapientia quam iacientes; et omnia desiderabilia ei non conparantur.
verses.english: For wisdom is better than jewels, and nothing desired is comparable to it.

verses.latin: Ego sapientia habito in consilio, et eruditis intersum cogitationibus.
verses.english: “I, Wisdom, dwell in counsel. I am present in thoughtful consideration.

verses.latin: Timor Domini odit malum; superbiam, et arrogantiam, et viam pravam, et os bilingue detestor.
verses.english: To fear the Lord is to hate evil. I hate pride, arrogance, a bad path, and a deceitful mouth.

verses.latin: Meum est consilium, et aequitas; mea prudentia, mea fortitudo.
verses.english: I have counsel and righteousness. I have prudence, I have strength.

verses.latin: Per me reges regnant, et potentes decernunt justa.
verses.english: By me, kings reign, and rulers decree what is just.

verses.latin: Per me principes imperant, et potentes decernunt justitiam.
verses.english: Through me, princes command, and the powerful decree justice.

verses.latin: Ego diligentes me diligo; et qui mane me quaerunt, invenient me.
verses.english: I love those who love me. Those who seek me early will find me.

verses.latin: Dives et gloria mecum sunt, opes et justitia.
verses.english: Riches and glory are with me, as are wealth and righteousness.

verses.latin: Melior est fructus meus auro et lapide pretioso; et genimina mea argento electo.
verses.english: My fruit is better than gold and precious stones; and my produce is better than refined silver.

verses.latin: In viis justitiae ambulo, in medio semitarum judicii.
verses.english: I walk in the way of righteousness, in the middle of the paths of judgment.

verses.latin: Ut ditem diligentes me, et repleam thesauros eorum.
verses.english: So that I may enrich those who love me and fill their treasuries.

verses.latin: Dominus possedit me in initio viarum suarum, antequam quidquam faceret a principio.
verses.english: The Lord created me at the beginning of His ways, before He made anything else.

verses.latin: Ab aeterno ordinata sum, et ex antiquo, antequam terra fieret.
verses.english: From eternity, I was ordained, from the beginning, before the earth was made.

verses.latin: Nondum erant abyssi, et ego jam concepta fui; necdum fontes aquarum scaturiebant:
verses.english: Before there were deep seas, I was already conceived; before the springs of water flowed forth:

verses.latin: necdum montes gravi mole constiterant, ante colles ego parturiebar.
verses.english: Before the mountains were formed, I was born before the hills.

verses.latin: Nondum terram fecerat, et flumina, et fundamina orbis terrae.
verses.english: Before He had made the land, the rivers, and the foundations of the earth, I was there.

verses.latin: Quando praeparabat caelos, aderam; quando certa lege, et gyro vallabat abyssos:
verses.english: When He prepared the universe, I was there; when He established the sky above the oceans,

verses.latin: quando aequabat nubes sursum, et firmabat fontes abyssorum:
verses.english: when He strengthened the clouds above, and secured the fountains of the deep,

verses.latin: quando ponebat mari terminum suum, et legem, ne transiret aquae, quando adpendebat fundamenta terrae:
verses.english: when He established the sea's boundaries, and a law so the water wouldn't cross them, and when He laid the foundations of the earth,

verses.latin: cum eo eram cuncta conponens: et delectabar quotidie, ludens coram eo omni tempore;
verses.english: then I was with Him, arranging everything. And I rejoiced daily, playing before Him all the time,

verses.latin: ludens in orbe terrarum; et deliciae meae esse cum filiis hominum.
verses.english: playing in the world; and my delight was to be with the children of men.

verses.latin: Nunc ergo, filii, audite me: beati, qui custodiunt vias meas.
verses.english: So now, children, listen to me: blessed are those who keep my ways.

verses.latin: Audite disciplinam, et estote sapientes, et nolite abjicere eam.
verses.english: Listen to instruction and be wise; do not cast it away.

verses.latin: Beatus homo, qui audit me, et qui vigilat ad fores meas quotidie, et observat ad postes ostii mei.
verses.english: Blessed is the man who hears me, and who watches at my doors every day, and observes the posts of my doors.

verses.latin: Qui me invenerit, inveniet vitam, et hauriet salutem a Domino.
verses.english: Whoever finds me finds life and will receive salvation from the Lord.

verses.latin: Qui autem in me peccaverit, laedet animam suam; omnes qui me oderunt, amant mortem.
verses.english: But whoever sins against me harms his own soul. All who hate me love death.

verses.latin: SAPIENTIA aedificavit sibi domum, excidit columnas septem.
verses.english: Wisdom has built herself a house; she has carved out seven columns.

verses.latin: Immolavit victimas suas, miscuit vinum, et posuit mensam.
verses.english: She has prepared her sacrifices, mixed her wine, and set up her table.

verses.latin: Misit ancillas suas ut vocaret a turribus, et moenibus civitatis:
verses.english: She sent her servants to call out from the highest points and the walls of the city:

verses.latin: Quicumque est parvulus, veniat ad me: et insipientibus locuta est:
verses.english: "Whoever is young, let him come to me," and she spoke to those who lacked understanding:

verses.latin: Venite, comedite de pane meo, et bibite vinum quod miscui vobis:
verses.english: "Come, eat my bread, and drink the wine I have mixed for you:

verses.latin: Relinquite insipientiam, et vivite, et ambulate per viam prudentiae.
verses.english: Abandon your ignorance, and you will live, and walk in the path of prudence."

verses.latin: Qui docet derisorem, ipse se inuriet: et qui arguit impium, sibi maculam generat.
verses.english: He who instructs a scoffer harms himself; he who reproves the wicked brings shame upon himself.

verses.latin: Noli arguere derisorem, ne oderit te: argue sapientem, et diliget te.
verses.english: Do not reprove a scoffer, lest he hate you; reprove a wise man, and he will love you.

verses.latin: Da sapienti occasionem, et addetur ei sapientia: doce justum, et addet ut accipiat.
verses.english: Give an opportunity to a wise man, and wisdom will be added to him; teach a just man, and he will increase in his learning.

verses.latin: Timor Domini principium sapientiae: et scientia sanctorum, prudentia.
verses.english: Fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom, and the knowledge of the saints is prudence.

verses.latin: Per me multiplicabuntur dies tui, et addentur tibi anni vitae.
verses.english: Through me, your days will be multiplied, and years of life will be added to you.

verses.latin: Si sapiens fueris, tibi ipsi eris: sin autem derisor, solus portabis malum.
verses.english: If you are wise, you are wise for yourself; if you are a scoffer, you alone will bear the evil.

verses.latin: Stultitia mulier clamosa et stulta, et nihil sciens.
verses.english: Folly is a loud, foolish woman, knowing nothing.

verses.latin: Et sedet in foribus domus suae, super sellam, in excelsis urbis,
verses.english: She sits at the doors of her house, on a seat, in the high places of the city,

verses.latin: ut vocet praetereuntes per viam, qui eunt gressibus suis:
verses.english: to call out to those passing by on the road, who go on their way:

verses.latin: Quicumque est parvulus, veniat ad me: et insipienti locuta est:
verses.english: "Whoever is young, let him come to me;" and she spoke to the foolish:

verses.latin: Aqua furtiva dulcior est, et panis absconditus suavior.
verses.english: “Stolen water is sweeter, and hidden bread is more pleasant."

verses.latin: Et ignorat quod ibi sint mortui, quod in profundis inferni convivę ejus.
verses.english: But she does not know that the dead are there, and that her guests are in the depths of hell.

verses.latin: Proverbia Salomonis. Filius sapiens laetificat patrem, filius vero stultus moeror matris suae.
verses.english: Proverbs of Solomon. A wise son brings joy to his father, but a foolish son is the sadness of his mother.

verses.latin: Non proderunt thesauri impietatis, justitia vero liberabit a morte.
verses.english: Treasures gained through evil will not last, but righteousness delivers from death.

verses.latin: Non patietur Dominus famem justi, et insatiabile desiderium impiorum expellit.
verses.english: The Lord will not let the just go hungry, but He sends away the desires of the wicked.

verses.latin: Manum segnium pauperes facit: manus autem fortium divitias parat.
verses.english: A lazy hand makes a man poor, but the hand of the diligent brings wealth.

verses.latin: Qui congregat in messe, filius sapiens est: qui autem stertit in aestate, filius ignominiosus.
verses.english: He who gathers in the harvest is a wise son, but he who sleeps during the harvest is a shameful son.

verses.latin: Benedictio Domini super caput justi: os autem impiorum operit iniquitatem.
verses.english: Blessings are on the head of the just, but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.

verses.latin: Memoria justi cum laudibus, et nomen impiorum putrescet.
verses.english: The memory of the just is blessed, but the name of the wicked rots.

verses.latin: Sapiens corde suscipiet mandata, stultus vero ore se frustrabit.
verses.english: The wise of heart receives the commandments, but a fool will be ruined by his own mouth.

verses.latin: Qui ambulat simpliciter, ambulat confidenter: qui autem pervertit vias suas, manifestus erit.
verses.english: He who walks uprightly walks securely, but he who perverts his ways will be exposed.

verses.latin: Qui annuit oculo, dabit dolorem: et stultus ore confabulabitur.
verses.english: He who winks with his eye causes grief, and a fool will chatter foolishly.

verses.latin: Fons vitae os justi, os impiorum operit iniquitatem.
verses.english: The mouth of the just is a fountain of life, but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.

verses.latin: Odium suscitat rixas, et universa quae non operiunt, stultus profert.
verses.english: Hatred stirs up disputes, and the fool reveals all that he does not want covered.

verses.latin: In labiis sapientis invenitur sapientia, et virga in dorso ejus qui indiget corde.
verses.english: On the lips of the wise is found wisdom, and a rod is on the back of him who lacks heart.

verses.latin: Sapiens abscondit scientiam, os autem stulti confestim prope est contritio.
verses.english: The wise hides knowledge, but the mouth of the fool is near to ruin.

verses.latin: Substantia divitis, urbs fortissima ejus: timor pauperum, eversio eorum.
verses.english: The wealth of the rich is their strong city, but the fear of the poor is their ruin.

verses.latin: Opus justi ad vitam, et doctrina impii ad peccatum.
verses.english: The work of the just leads to life, but the teachings of the wicked lead to sin.

verses.latin: Via vitae custodienti disciplinam, qui autem increpationes relinquit, errat.
verses.english: The path of life is for those who keep discipline, but he who abandons reproof errs.

verses.latin: Qui abscondit odium, mendax est labiis: et qui profert calumniam, stultus est.
verses.english: He who conceals hatred is a liar with his lips, and he who spreads slander is a fool.

verses.latin: In multiloquio non deerit peccatum: qui moderatur labia sua, prudentissimus est.
verses.english: In much talk, sin will not be absent, but he who restrains his lips is most prudent.

verses.latin: Lingua justi argentum electum: cor impiorum quasi nihil.
verses.english: The tongue of the just is choice silver, but the heart of the wicked is of little value.

verses.latin: Labia justi pascunt plurimos: morientes autem stulti dolore contristantur.
verses.english: The lips of the just feed many, but fools are grieved by their own folly.

verses.latin: Benedictio Domini ditat, nec afferet ei curam.
verses.english: The blessing of the Lord makes rich, and He adds no sorrow with it.

verses.latin: Operari facinora quasi risus stulto: sapientia autem viro prudenti, est gaudium.
verses.english: Doing wickedness is like sport to a fool, but wisdom is joy to a man of understanding.

verses.latin: Quod timet impius, eveniet ei: desiderium justorum adimplietur.
verses.english: What the wicked fears will come upon him, but the desire of the just will be granted.

verses.latin: Quasi turbo pertransiens, non erit impius: justus autem quasi fundamentum sempiternum.
verses.english: As a whirlwind passes, so the wicked will not remain, but the just is like an everlasting foundation.

verses.latin: Sicut acetum dentibus, et fumus oculis, ita piger his qui miserunt eum.
verses.english: As vinegar to the teeth, and smoke to the eyes, so is the lazy person to those who sent him.

verses.latin: Timor Domini addet dies, et anni impiorum breviabuntur.
verses.english: The fear of the Lord prolongs days, but the years of the wicked will be shortened.

verses.latin: Expectatio justorum laetitia: spes impiorum peribit.
verses.english: The hope of the just is joy, but the hope of the wicked will perish.

verses.latin: Fortitudo simplicis via Domini, et pavor eorum qui operantur malum.
verses.english: The way of the Lord is strength to the upright, and fear to those who do evil.

verses.latin: Justus in aeternum non commovebitur: impii autem non habitabunt terram.
verses.english: The just will never be moved, but the wicked will not inhabit the land.

verses.latin: Os justi proferet sapientiam: lingua pravorum peribit.
verses.english: The mouth of the just produces wisdom, but the tongue of the wicked will perish.

verses.latin: Statera dolosa abominabilis est coram Domino: pondus autem justum placabile ei.
verses.english: God hates dishonesty in the marketplace. Honest scales, however, bring Him joy.

verses.latin: Ubi venerit superbia, ibi et contumelia: ubi autem humilitas, ibi et sapientia.
verses.english: Pride brings disgrace, but humility brings wisdom.

verses.latin: Simplici via justorum dirigit eos justitia: et perversitas praevaricatorum scandalum est illis.
verses.english: The integrity of the upright guides them, but the crookedness of the treacherous destroys them.

verses.latin: Non proderunt divitiæ in die iræ: justitia vero liberat a morte.
verses.english: Wealth does not help when God’s anger comes, but justice will save from death.

verses.latin: Justitia viri perfecti dirigit viam ejus: et in impietate impius corruet.
verses.english: The justice of the blameless keeps his way straight, but the wicked will fall.

verses.latin: Justitia rectorum liberabit eos: et in voluntate eorum capientur improbi.
verses.english: The righteousness of the upright will deliver them, but the wicked will be caught in their own desires.

verses.latin: Mortuo homine impio, periit et spes ejus: et expectatio in fortibus, peribit.
verses.english: When the wicked dies, his hope dies, and the expectation of wealth comes to nothing.

verses.latin: Justus de angustia eripitur: et tradetur pro eo impius.
verses.english: The righteous are delivered from trouble, but the wicked take the righteous’ place.

verses.latin: Simulator ore decipit amicum suum: justi autem liberabuntur scientia.
verses.english: With his mouth, a hypocrite destroys his neighbor, but the righteous are delivered by knowledge.

verses.latin: In bono justorum exultabit civitas: et in perditione impiorum erit exultatio.
verses.english: When the righteous prosper, the city rejoices, and when the wicked perish, there are shouts of joy.

verses.latin: Benedictione justorum exaltabitur civitas: os autem impiorum dissipabit eam.
verses.english: A city prospers when the righteous bless it, but the wicked destroy it by their words.

verses.latin: Qui despicit amicum, indigens est corde: et in labore suo confodietur.
verses.english: Those who despise their neighbors are fools, but those with understanding hold their tongues.

verses.latin: Ambulans fraudulenter revelat arcana: qui autem fidelis est animi, celat negotium.
verses.english: A gossip reveals secrets, but a trustworthy person keeps a confidence.

verses.latin: Ubi non est gubernator, populus corruet: salus autem ubi multa consilia.
verses.english: Without guidance, a nation falls, but with many counselors there is safety.

verses.latin: Affligendo se pro alio, malum facit: qui autem odit contractus, securior est.
verses.english: He who guarantees a debt is surely harmed, and whoever hates suretyship is safe.

verses.latin: Mulier gratiosa inveniet gloriam: et fortes possidebunt divitias.
verses.english: A gracious woman gains honor, and strong men gain wealth.

verses.latin: Benefacit animæ suæ vir misericors: qui autem crudelis est, conturbat carnem suam.
verses.english: The merciful man does good to his own soul, but the cruel troubles his own flesh.

verses.latin: Impius facit opus instabile: qui autem seminat justitiam, merces vera.
verses.english: The wicked earns wages that are false, but he who sows righteousness gets a true reward.

verses.latin: Qui in justitia stat, vitam persequitur: et qui sequitur malum, morti occurret.
verses.english: He who is righteous has life, and he who pursues evil seeks his own death.

verses.latin: Abominatio Domini, cor pravum: et voluntas rectarum, placabilis.
verses.english: The Lord hates those with a crooked heart, but He delights in those whose way is blameless.

verses.latin: Manus in manu non est impune: semen autem justorum liberabitur.
verses.english: Assuredly, the wicked shall not be unpunished: but the seed of the just shall be saved.

verses.latin: Sicut in circulo auri in naribus suis sus, sic mulier speciosa et stulta.
verses.english: As a gold ring in a pig's snout, so is a beautiful woman who lacks good judgment.

verses.latin: Desiderium justorum omne bonum: expectatio impiorum ira.
verses.english: The desire of the righteous is only good, but the expectation of the wicked will be wrath.

verses.latin: Est qui tribuit, et ditior fit: et qui rapit, quasi semper egeat.
verses.english: There are those who give freely, and become more wealthy. Others withhold what they should give, and become impoverished.

verses.latin: Anima benedicta impinguabitur: et qui inebrians est, ipse inebriabitur.
verses.english: A generous person will be blessed, and he who waters will also be watered.

verses.latin: Qui abscondit frumentum, maledictus a populis: benedictio autem super caput vendentium.
verses.english: People curse those who hoard grain, but blessings are on the head of the one who sells it.

verses.latin: Qui studet bene, diligit bonum: qui autem requirit malum, ipsum inveniet.
verses.english: He who seeks good will find favor, but evil comes to him who searches for it.

verses.latin: Qui confidit in divitiis suis, corruet: justi autem quasi virens folium germinabunt.
verses.english: He who trusts in his wealth will fall, but the righteous will flourish like green leaves.

verses.latin: Qui conturbat domum suam, possidebit ventum: et stultus serviet sapienti.
verses.english: He who brings trouble on his household will inherit the wind, and the fool will be the servant of the wise.

verses.latin: Fructus justi lignum vitæ: et qui ganat animas, sapiens est.
verses.english: The fruit of the righteous is a tree of life, and he who wins souls is wise.

verses.latin: Si justus in terra recipit, quanto magis impius et peccator?
verses.english: If the righteous will be rewarded on earth, how much more the wicked and the sinner?

verses.latin: Qui diligit disciplinam, diligit scientiam: qui autem odit correptionem, stultus est.
verses.english: The one who loves discipline also loves knowledge; but the one who hates being corrected is a fool.

verses.latin: Bonus per voluntatem obtinebit a Domino: vir autem malorum condemnabitur.
verses.english: God gives blessings to those who do good; but He will condemn evil men.

verses.latin: Non confirmabitur homo in impietate: radix autem justorum non commovebitur.
verses.english: No one will ever become secure through wickedness, but those with righteousness will stand firm.

verses.latin: Mulier fortis corona est viri sui: quae turpiter agit, tabes ossium ejus.
verses.english: A good wife is a crown to her husband; but the one who does shameful things wastes her husband's strength.

verses.latin: Cogitationes justorum judicia: et consilia impiorum insidiæ.
verses.english: The thoughts of the righteous are just, and the plans of the wicked are full of traps.

verses.latin: Verba impiorum insidiantur sanguini: os justorum liberabit eos.
verses.english: The words of the wicked are a trap, leading to bloodshed, while the righteous will always be delivered.

verses.latin: Subvertuntur impii, et non subsistent: domus autem justorum permanebit.
verses.english: The wicked will fall and never rise, but the homes of the just will remain.

verses.latin: Vir laudabitur pro sensu suo: qui vero stultus est corde, erit despectus.
verses.english: Men will be praised based on their wisdom; but those foolish in their hearts will be despised.

verses.latin: Melior est pauper, et sufficiens, quam gloriatur, et indiget pane.
verses.english: It is better to be poor with the bare necessities than to be arrogant and still in need of food.

verses.latin: Justus novit animas jumentorum suorum: viscera autem impiorum crudelia.
verses.english: The righteous know the needs of their animals, but the heart of the wicked is cruel.

verses.latin: Qui operatur terram, saturabitur panibus: qui sectatur otiosos, stultus est.
verses.english: The one who works his land will have more than enough food; but the one who chases after empty pleasures is a fool.

verses.latin: Desiderium impiorum mala: radix autem justorum germinabit.
verses.english: The wicked desire evil, but the root of the righteous bears fruit.

verses.latin: Peccatum labiorum, laqueus est peccatoribus: et qui timet, procul dubio liberabitur.
verses.english: The sin of the lips will trap sinners, but those who avoid sin will be freed.

verses.latin: De fructu oris viri implebitur bonis: retributio operis manuum ejus reddetur ei.
verses.english: The good will be filled by the fruits of their words, and the work of their hands will be rewarded.

verses.latin: Via stulti recta in oculis ejus: qui autem sapiens est, audit consilia.
verses.english: The way of the fool seems right to him, but the wise listen to counsel.

verses.latin: Stultus statim indicat iram suam: qui dissimulat ignominiam, est callidus.
verses.english: A fool immediately makes his anger known, but the one who ignores insults is wise.

verses.latin: Qui profert quod novit, annuntiat justitiam: qui autem testis est mendacii, dolus est.
verses.english: He who tells the truth is just, but he who is a false witness is a fraud.

verses.latin: Est, qui promittit, et quasi lanceat gladio: lingua autem sapientium sanitas.
verses.english: There are those who speak rashly as if they are stabbing with a sword, but the tongue of the wise brings health.

verses.latin: Labium verax permanebit in æternum: et testis velox, brevi tempore.
verses.english: The truthful lip will endure forever, and the lying witness will be silenced quickly.

verses.latin: Dolus in corde eorum qui cogitant mala: gaudentes autem in consiliis pacis.
verses.english: Deceit is in the heart of those who plot evil, but those who counsel peace rejoice.

verses.latin: Non contristabit justum quidquid ei acciderit: impii autem replebuntur malo.
verses.english: No evil will ever befall the righteous, but the wicked are full of trouble.

verses.latin: Labia mendaciorum abominantur Domino: qui autem fideliter agunt, placabunt eum.
verses.english: Lying lips are an abomination to God, but those who act faithfully please Him.

verses.latin: Homo astutus celat scientiam: cor stultorum annuntiabit stultitiam.
verses.english: A clever man hides knowledge, but the foolish heart will proclaim foolishness.

verses.latin: Manus fortium dominabitur: otiosa vero, tributo subjacebit.
verses.english: The hand of the strong rules, but the lazy will be subject to tribute.

verses.latin: Tristitia in corde viri curvo, conteret eum: sermone bono lætificabitur.
verses.english: Sadness in the heart of a man bows him down, but a good word makes him happy.

verses.latin: Qui negligit amicum suum, pro nihilo habebitur: qui autem timet, corripitur.
verses.english: He who neglects his friend is worthless, but the one who fears is corrected.

verses.latin: Non veniet in mendacio qui diligit disciplinam: vir autem mendax conturbabitur.
verses.english: The one who loves discipline does not lie, but a man of lies is troubled.

verses.latin: In via justitiæ vita: et semita erroris ad mortem.
verses.english: In the way of righteousness is life, and the path of error leads to death.

verses.latin: Qui custodit disciplinam, in via vitæ est: qui autem correptiones relinquit, errat.
verses.english: The one who keeps discipline is on the path of life, but the one who rejects correction goes astray.

verses.latin: Qui continet linguam suam, novit scientiam: qui autem impatiens est lingua, stultus est.
verses.english: He who controls his tongue knows knowledge, but the impatient of tongue is a fool.

verses.latin: Qui timet Deum, suscipiet bona: et fructus ejus, erunt in plenitudine.
verses.english: The one who fears God will receive blessings, and the rewards will be abundant.

verses.latin: Via stulti recta in oculis ejus: qui autem sapiens est, audit consilia.
verses.english: The way of the fool is right in his own eyes, but the wise listen to counsel.

verses.latin: Nescitur malum justo: impii autem replebuntur malo.
verses.english: No evil will befall the just, but the wicked will be filled with evil.

verses.latin: Filius sapiens cor patris laetificat: filius vero stultus, moeror matris suae.
verses.english: A wise son makes his father's heart happy; but a foolish son is his mother's grief.

verses.latin: Thesauri impietatis nihil proderunt: justitia vero liberat a morte.
verses.english: Ill-gotten gains are worthless, but justice saves from death.

verses.latin: Non derelinquet Dominus esurientes justitia: insatiabilem vero impiorum reprobabit.
verses.english: The Lord won’t let the just go hungry, but He frustrates the ambitions of the wicked.

verses.latin: Piger manu, pauperem facit: manus autem fortium opes congregat.
verses.english: Lazy hands make a man poor, but diligent hands bring wealth.

verses.latin: Filius sapiens in messe congregat: qui autem dormit in aestate, filius confusionis.
verses.english: A wise son gathers in harvest, but the one who sleeps in summer is a cause for shame.

verses.latin: Benedictiones Domini super caput justi: os autem impiorum operiet iniquitatem.
verses.english: Blessings come on the head of the just, but the mouth of the wicked is filled with violence.

verses.latin: Memoria justi cum laudibus: nomen autem impiorum putrescet.
verses.english: The memory of the just is a blessing, but the name of the wicked will rot.

verses.latin: Sapiens corde suscipit mandata: stultus vero linguis confractus apparebit.
verses.english: The wise of heart accepts instructions, but a babbling fool will come to ruin.

verses.latin: Qui ambulat simpliciter, ambulat confidenter: qui autem depravat vias suas, manifestus erit.
verses.english: The one who walks honestly walks securely, but the one who twists his ways will be known.

verses.latin: Qui nutu significat oculos, dat dolorem: et stultus linguis confractus apparebit.
verses.english: The one who winks knowingly causes grief, and a babbling fool will come to ruin.

verses.latin: Fons vitae, doctrina justi: calumniae vero impiorum, laqueus mortis.
verses.english: The teaching of the just is a fountain of life, but the snare of death is the violence of the wicked.

verses.latin: Timor Domini, fiducia fortis filio: et relinquet filiis timorem suum.
verses.english: Fear of the Lord is a strong confidence for a son, and He will leave this to his sons.

verses.latin: Disciplina stultorum, stultitia: sapientia parvulorum, prudentia.
verses.english: Foolishness is the discipline of fools; wisdom is prudence to the young.

verses.latin: Qui custodit os suum, custodit animam suam: qui autem inconsideratus est ad loquendum, sentiet mala.
verses.english: The one who guards his mouth guards his soul; but the one who speaks rashly will experience evil.

verses.latin: Voluntas pigeri, occidet eum: noluerunt enim manus ejus operari.
verses.english: The lazy man’s desire kills him, because his hands refuse to work.

verses.latin: Tractantes diligentiam, vitam possidebunt: qui autem negligunt viam suam, morientur.
verses.english: Those who practice diligence will live, but those who neglect their way will die.

verses.latin: Qui celat odium, mendax est labiis: qui autem exprimit calumniam, stultus est.
verses.english: The one who conceals hatred is a liar with his lips, but the one who spreads slander is a fool.

verses.latin: In multiloquio, peccatum non defuit: qui autem moderatur labia sua, prudentissimus est.
verses.english: In much talk, sin is not lacking, but the one who controls his lips is most wise.

verses.latin: Lingua justi, electa argentum: cor impiorum, ad nihilum redigetur.
verses.english: The tongue of the just is like choice silver; but the heart of the wicked is of no value.

verses.latin: Cor sapientis quaerit scientiam: os stultorum pascitur stultitia.
verses.english: The heart of the wise seeks knowledge, but the mouth of fools feeds on foolishness.

verses.latin: Qui sequitur justitiam et misericordiam, inveniet vitam et justitiam cum gloria.
verses.english: The one who follows justice and mercy will find life and honor and glory.

verses.latin: Ascendit sapiens urbem fortium, et destruit robur fiducia illorum.
verses.english: A wise man climbs the city of the strong, and destroys the strength of their confidence.

verses.latin: Qui custodit os suum et linguam suam, custodit ab angustiis animam suam.
verses.english: The one who guards his mouth and his tongue protects his soul from trouble.

verses.latin: Superbus et arrogans vocatur ludibrium: et operatur superbia cum indignatione.
verses.english: A proud and arrogant man is called a joke, and he acts with arrogance and indignation.

verses.latin: Desideria pigeri occidunt eum: quia noluerunt manus ejus operari.
verses.english: The lazy man’s desires kill him, because his hands have not wanted to work.

verses.latin: Tota die concupiscit avarus: qui autem dat, et non cessat, impinguabitur.
verses.english: The greedy man covets all day, but the one who gives and does not cease is enriched.

verses.latin: Victima impiorum abominabilis: et oblatio justorum, electa.
verses.english: The sacrifice of the wicked is abominable, but the offering of the just is chosen.

verses.latin: Qui calumniam spernit, diligitur: qui autem timetur ab impio, peribit.
verses.english: The one who despises slander is loved, but the one who fears the wicked will perish.

verses.latin: Sapiens in malis timet, et declinat a malis: stultus transilit, et confidit.
verses.english: The wise man fears evil and turns from it, but the fool charges ahead and is confident.

verses.latin: Pauper, et creditor, occurrent sibi: utriusque oculos illuminat Dominus.
verses.english: The poor and the creditor will meet each other, for the Lord illuminates the eyes of them both.

verses.latin: Qui instruit puerum, diligitur a filiis: et maneat in filiis ejus fructus operis ejus.
verses.english: The one who instructs a child is loved by the sons, and the fruit of his work remains with his sons.

verses.latin: Sapiens aedificabit sibi domum, et stabiliet eam septem columnis.
verses.english: A wise person will build a home for himself, and will strengthen it with seven pillars.

verses.latin: Stulta exaedificabit sibi domum, quae stultitia sua destruit.
verses.english: A foolish person builds a home that is destroyed by his own foolishness.

verses.latin: Qui graditur per vias rectas, timens Deum, despicitur a contemnentibus viam pravam.
verses.english: The one who walks the correct way, fearing God, is scorned by those who despise the straight path.

verses.latin: In corde stultorum habitabit scientia, et non intelleget eam.
verses.english: In the heart of a fool, understanding will be present, and they will not understand it.

verses.latin: Fidelis testis non mentitur: profert mendacium dolosus testis.
verses.english: A faithful witness does not lie, but a deceitful witness speaks falsehood.

verses.latin: Quaerit derisor sapientiam et non invenit: scientia viro prudenti facilis.
verses.english: The scoffer seeks wisdom and does not find it, but knowledge is easy for a prudent man.

verses.latin: Recede a viro stulto: in labiis ejus nescies prudentiam.
verses.english: Stay away from a foolish man, because you will not find wisdom in his words.

verses.latin: Sapientia callidi est intelligere viam suam; et stultitia stultorum error.
verses.english: The wisdom of the shrewd is to understand his own way, but the foolishness of fools is their error.

verses.latin: Stulti illudent pro peccato, et in medio justorum gratia.
verses.english: Fools mock at sin, but grace is with the righteous.

verses.latin: Cor novit amaritudinem animae suae: et in gaudio illius non miscebitur extraneus.
verses.english: The heart knows the bitterness of its own soul, and a stranger will not share in its joy.

verses.latin: Domus impiorum subvertetur: tabernaculum justorum florebit.
verses.english: The house of the wicked will be overturned, but the dwelling of the just will flourish.

verses.latin: Est via, quae videtur homini recta, et novissima ejus deducunt ad mortem.
verses.english: There is a way that seems right to a man, but its end leads to death.

verses.latin: Ridens dolore replebitur: et gaudium ejus in gemitu terminabitur.
verses.english: Even in laughter, there is pain, and the end of joy is sorrow.

verses.latin: Viro in viis suis, a fructibus operum suorum replebitur.
verses.english: A man will be filled with the fruit of his works in his own ways.

verses.latin: Credulus omni verbo, is est stultus: sagax considerat gressus suos.
verses.english: The one who believes every word is foolish, but the wise one considers their steps.

verses.latin: Sapiens timet, et declinat a malo: stultus protervus et fiduciarius est.
verses.english: A wise person fears evil and avoids it, but a fool is bold and confident.

verses.latin: Iracundus facile provocatur: et homo qui cito offenditur, semper stultus.
verses.english: The quick-tempered man provokes a quarrel, and a man who is easily offended is always a fool.

verses.latin: Parvuli possidebunt stultitiam: et callidi coronabuntur doctrina.
verses.english: The immature will possess foolishness, but the shrewd will be crowned with knowledge.

verses.latin: Mali incurvabuntur coram bonis, et impii ad portas justorum.
verses.english: The wicked will bow before the good, and the impious at the gates of the just.

verses.latin: Pauper odibilis est etiam proximo suo: amici divitum multi.
verses.english: The poor are despised by even their neighbors, but the friends of the rich are many.

verses.latin: Qui despicit proximum suum, peccat: qui autem miseretur pauperis, beatus est.
verses.english: The one who despises their neighbor sins, but the one who takes pity on the poor is blessed.

verses.latin: Nonne errant qui operantur malum? misericordia et veritas praevalent operantibus bonum.
verses.english: Do not those who do evil err? Mercy and truth prevail for those who do good.

verses.latin: In omni opere erit abundantia: ubi autem verba otiosa, ibi egestas.
verses.english: In every work there will be abundance, but where there are idle words, there is poverty.

verses.latin: Sapientium fortitudo, divitiæ eorum: stultorum, inscientia eorum.
verses.english: The strength of the wise is their riches, but the foolishness of fools is their ignorance.

verses.latin: Testis fidelis liberat animas: et loquitur multa mendacia, vir dolosus.
verses.english: A faithful witness saves souls, but a deceitful man speaks many lies.

verses.latin: In timore Domini fiducia fortitudinis: et filiis ejus erit spes.
verses.english: In the fear of the Lord is the confidence of strength, and His sons will have hope.

verses.latin: Timor Domini, fons vitæ, ut recedat a laqueis mortis.
verses.english: The fear of the Lord is the fountain of life, and causes one to depart from the snares of death.

verses.latin: In multitudine populi, dignitas regis: et in paucitate plebis, ignominia principis.
verses.english: In the multitude of the people is the glory of the king, and in the lack of people, the shame of the prince.

verses.latin: Qui patiens est, multæ sapientiæ: et qui parvus est spiritu, exaltat stultitiam.
verses.english: The patient one is of great understanding, and the one who is small in spirit exalts foolishness.

verses.latin: Vita corporis, cor sanum: putredo ossium, invidia.
verses.english: A healthy heart is the life of the body, but envy is the rottenness of the bones.

verses.latin: Qui calumniatur pauperem, exprobrat Factorem suum: glorificat eum qui miseretur pauperi.
verses.english: The one who oppresses the poor insults his Maker, but the one who has mercy on the poor glorifies Him.

verses.latin: In malitia sua expellitur impius: spes autem justi, immortalitas.
verses.english: The wicked is driven away in his wickedness, but the hope of the just is immortality.

verses.latin: In corde prudentium requiescit sapientia: et in medio stultorum quasi non cognoscitur.
verses.english: Wisdom rests in the heart of the prudent, but in the midst of fools, it is as though it is not known.

verses.latin: Justitia exaltat gentem: miseros facit peccatum populorum.
verses.english: Justice exalts a nation, but sin makes peoples miserable.

verses.latin: Gratus est regi servus sapiens: qui vero turpis est, interibit.
verses.english: A wise servant is pleasing to the king, but the one who is shameful will perish.

verses.latin: Responsio mollis frangit iram: sermo durus suscitat furorem.
verses.english: A gentle answer will calm an angry person, but harsh words ignite rage.

verses.latin: Lingua sapientium ornat scientiam: os fatuorum ebullit stultitiam.
verses.english: Those with understanding express knowledge well, while the mouths of fools pour out folly.

verses.latin: In omni loco oculi Domini contemplantur bonos et malos.
verses.english: The eyes of the Lord observe what happens everywhere, watching the good and the evil.

verses.latin: Lingua concinnans lignum vitae: quae autem corrumpit, contristat spiritum.
verses.english: A wholesome tongue is a tree of life, but one that is twisted breaks the spirit.

verses.latin: Stultus contemnit disciplinam patris sui: qui autem custodit correptiones, prudentior erit.
verses.english: A fool scorns his father's discipline, but the one who accepts correction is wise.

verses.latin: In domo justi plurima fortitudo: in fructibus impii conturbatio.
verses.english: In the house of a righteous man, there is an abundance of strength. But the profits of the wicked cause turmoil.

verses.latin: Labia sapientium spargunt scientiam: cor fatuorum contrarium.
verses.english: The lips of the wise spread knowledge, but the hearts of fools are perverse.

verses.latin: Victima impiorum abominabilis Domino: vota justorum placabilia.
verses.english: The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination to the Lord, but the prayers of the just are pleasing to Him.

verses.latin: Via impii abominabilis Domino: qui autem sequitur justitiam, diligitur ab eo.
verses.english: The way of the wicked is an abomination to the Lord, but whoever follows righteousness is loved by Him.

verses.latin: Doctrina mala derelinquentem viam: qui odit arguitur, morietur.
verses.english: Stern discipline is for those who leave the right path. Whoever hates correction will die.

verses.latin: Infernus et perditio coram Domino: quanto magis corda filiorum hominum?
verses.english: Even hell and the place of destruction are known to the Lord; how much more the hearts of men?

verses.latin: Non amat irrisorem, qui arguitur: nec ad sapientes graditur.
verses.english: A scorner doesn't love being corrected, nor does he go to the wise.

verses.latin: Cor hilare gaudium parat: et in risu dolor miscebitur.
verses.english: A cheerful heart makes the face happy, and a sorrowful heart crushes the spirit.

verses.latin: Cor prudentis quaerit doctrinam: os stultorum pascitur stultitiam.
verses.english: The heart of the wise seeks understanding, but the mouth of fools feeds on folly.

verses.latin: Omnis dies pauperis malus: et cor laetum semper epulae.
verses.english: All the days of the poor are evil, but a cheerful heart has a continual feast.

verses.latin: Melius est modicum cum timore Domini: quam thesauri magni cum perturbatione.
verses.english: It is better to have a little with the fear of the Lord, than great treasure with trouble.

verses.latin: Melius est obsonare olera cum caritate: quam saginatum bovem cum odio.
verses.english: Better is a dinner of herbs where love is, than a fatted ox with hatred.

verses.latin: Vir iracundus provocat discordias: qui patiens est, mitigat lites.
verses.english: An angry man stirs up strife, but one who is patient settles quarrels.

verses.latin: Via pigrorum quasi sepes spinarum: via justorum absque offensu.
verses.english: The path of the lazy is like a hedge of thorns, but the path of the just is without offense.
