verses.latin: Filius sapiens laetificat patrem: stultus homo despicit matrem suam.
verses.english: A wise son makes a father happy, but a foolish man despises his mother.

verses.latin: Stultitia gaudium stulto: vir prudens dirigit gressus suos.
verses.english: Folly is joy to a fool, but a man of understanding directs his steps.

verses.latin: Dissipantur cogitationes ubi non est consilium: ubi vero multi consiliarii, confirmantur.
verses.english: Without counsel, thoughts are disappointed, but in a multitude of counselors they are established.

verses.latin: Verbum optime accommodatum in tempore: et quasi mala aurea in scutellis argenteis.
verses.english: A word fitly spoken at the proper time, is like apples of gold in settings of silver.

verses.latin: Qui arguitur a sapiente, plus proficit quam qui laudatur a stulto.
verses.english: He who is corrected by the wise profits more than he who is praised by a fool.

verses.latin: Sicut frigus nivis in die messis, ita nuntius fidelis his qui miserunt eum: animam ipsorum reficit.
verses.english: As the cold of snow in the time of harvest, so is a faithful messenger to those who sent him, refreshing the soul of his masters.

verses.latin: Qui aufert pallium in die frigoris: et aceti super nitrum, qui cantat carmina cordi contrito.
verses.english: Like one who takes off a garment in cold weather, like vinegar upon soda, is he that sings songs to a heavy heart.

verses.latin: Si esurierit inimicus tuus, ciba eum: si sitierit, potum da illi: hoc enim faciens, carbones ignis congeres super caput ejus.
verses.english: If your enemy hungers, feed him. If he thirsts, give him to drink. For by doing this, you will heap coals of fire upon his head.

verses.latin: Vir malus corruet in malis: justus sperabit in morte sua.
verses.english: A wicked man will fall into evils, but the just hopes in his death.

verses.latin: In corde sapientis requiescit sapientia: et in medio fatuorum quasi ignis urit.
verses.english: Wisdom rests in the heart of the wise, but in the midst of fools it makes itself known.

verses.latin: Justitia exaltat gentem: miseros facit populos peccatum.
verses.english: Righteousness exalts a nation, but sin makes the peoples miserable.

verses.latin: Obedientia justitiae via vitae: ut sequaris gloriam.
verses.english: The path of righteousness is the way of life, so that you can follow glory.

verses.latin: Hominis est disponere cordis sui: et Domini est gubernare linguam.
verses.english: The man plans in his heart how to accomplish a goal, but God directs the steps.

verses.latin: Omnes viae hominis patent oculis ejus: spirituum ponderator est Dominus.
verses.english: Man may believe his own actions are pure, but God assesses his spirit.

verses.latin: Revela Domino opera tua, et dirigentur cogitationes tuae.
verses.english: Dedicate your actions to the Lord, and your goals will be fulfilled.

verses.latin: Universa propter semetipsum operatus est Dominus: impium quoque ad diem malum.
verses.english: God created everything for His own purposes, even the wicked for the day of judgment.

verses.latin: Abominatio est Domino omnis qui superbis est corde: et quod manum dederit, non erit innocens.
verses.english: The Lord detests anyone with a proud heart. Though hand joins in hand, the wicked won't escape punishment.

verses.latin: Misericordia et veritate expiatur iniquitas: et in timore Domini declinatur a malis.
verses.english: Through mercy and truth, evil is cleansed, and through the fear of the Lord, people turn away from sin.

verses.latin: Cum placuerint Domino viae hominis, et inimicos ejus convertet ad pacem.
verses.english: When God is pleased with a man's ways, He makes even the man's enemies peaceful.

verses.latin: Melius est modicum cum justitia, quam multi fructus cum iniquitate.
verses.english: It is better to live a simple life justly than to have much wealth unjustly.

verses.latin: Cor hominis disponit viam suam: sed Domini est dirigere gressus ejus.
verses.english: A man makes plans, but God directs his steps.

verses.latin: Divinatio in labiis regis: in judicio non errabit os ejus.
verses.english: The king's decisions are divinely inspired; his words, when he judges, are right.

verses.latin: Statera et stateram judicii Domini sunt: et operis ejus omnes lapides sacculi.
verses.english: The Lord requires fair scales and balances. All weights and measures are His work.

verses.latin: Abominabiles sunt regibus qui agunt impietatem: quoniam in justitia stabilitur solium.
verses.english: Kings should hate wicked actions, for it is justice that secures a throne.

verses.latin: Voluntas justorum beneplacitum regum: et opera justorum diliget.
verses.english: Righteous speech pleases kings, and they love those who speak what is right.

verses.latin: Ira regis nuntii mortis: vir autem sapiens placabit eam.
verses.english: A king's anger is a messenger of death, but a wise man can calm it.

verses.latin: In vultu regis vita: et quasi imber serotinus benignitas ejus.
verses.english: When a king smiles, it is life. His favor is like a refreshing late rain.

verses.latin: Possidere sapientiam, quam aurum: et obtinere prudentiam, magis quam argentum.
verses.english: It is better to gain wisdom than gold, and to have prudence more than silver.

verses.latin: Viam malorum declinat: qui timet Deum: qui autem observat viam suam, conservat animam suam.
verses.english: The person who fears God turns away from evil. Whoever is careful with their path protects their soul.

verses.latin: Ante ruinam superbia, et ante casum spiritus elationis.
verses.english: Pride comes before destruction, and a haughty spirit before a fall.

verses.latin: Melius est humiliari cum mitibus, quam dividere spolia superborum.
verses.english: It is better to be humble with the meek than to divide spoils with the proud.

verses.latin: Qui intelligit verbum, inveniet bonum: et qui sperat in Domino, beatus est.
verses.english: The one who understands a teaching prospers, and happy is the one who trusts in the Lord.

verses.latin: Qui sapiens est corde, appellabitur prudens: et qui dulcis in lingua, major habebit gratiam.
verses.english: The wise in heart is called intelligent, and the one with a gentle tongue wins favor.

verses.latin: Fons vitae doctrina sapientiae: et doctrina fatuorum stultitia.
verses.english: Wisdom is a fountain of life to the wise, but the correction of fools is folly.

verses.latin: Cor sapientis erudiet os ejus: et labiis ejus addet gratiam.
verses.english: The heart of the wise teaches their mouth, and it adds grace to their lips.

verses.latin: Favo mellis faventes verba: dulcedo animæ et sanitas ossium.
verses.english: Pleasant words are like a honeycomb: sweetness to the soul and health to the bones.

verses.latin: Est via, quae videtur homini justa: novissima ejus deducunt ad mortem.
verses.english: There is a way that seems right to a person, but its end leads to death.

verses.latin: Anima laborantis laborat sibi: quia necessitas compulit eum.
verses.english: A working person labors for themselves, because their need compels them.

verses.latin: Vir impius fodit malum: et in labiis ejus ignis ardens.
verses.english: A wicked man digs up evil, and on his lips is a scorching fire.

verses.latin: Vir perversus suscitat lites: et qui detrahit, separat amicos.
verses.english: A dishonest man stirs up conflict, and a gossip separates friends.

verses.latin: Vir iniquus impellit amicum suum: et quasi per viam non bonam ducit eum.
verses.english: A violent man deceives his neighbor and leads him on a path that isn't good.

verses.latin: Qui corruit oculos suos ad cogitandum perversum: mordens labia sua, perficit malum.
verses.english: The one who winks with his eyes plans deceit, and one who purses his lips performs evil.

verses.latin: Corona gloriae senectus, quae invenitur in viis justitiae.
verses.english: Gray hair is a crown of glory; it is found in a life of righteousness.

verses.latin: Melior est patiens fortiori: et qui dominatur animo suo, expugnatore urbium.
verses.english: The patient person is better than the warrior, and the one who controls his temper is greater than a city conqueror.

verses.latin: In sinu mittitur sors: sed a Domino gubernantur omnia.
verses.english: The lot is cast into the lap, but all its decision is of the Lord.

verses.latin: Melior est buccella sicca cum gaudio, quam domus plena victimis cum jurgio.
verses.english: It is better to eat a dry crust of bread in joy, than to have a house filled with sacrificial feasts, but also with strife.

verses.latin: Servus sapiens dominabitur filio stulto, et inter fratres hereditatem dividet.
verses.english: A wise servant will have authority over a foolish son, and will share in the inheritance with the other brothers.

verses.latin: Caminus ad probandum argentum et fornax aurum: probator autem cordium est Dominus.
verses.english: As fire refines silver and a furnace refines gold, so the Lord examines hearts.

verses.latin: Malus obediens linguae iniquae, et stultus cito inruit.
verses.english: An evildoer heeds the tongue of a liar, and the foolish quickly get into trouble.

verses.latin: Qui deridet pauperem, exprobrat Factorem suum: et qui laetatur in calamitate alterius, non erit impunitus.
verses.english: He who mocks the poor insults his Maker. He who rejoices over another's misfortune will not go unpunished.

verses.latin: Corona senum filii filiorum: et gloria filiorum, patres eorum.
verses.english: Grandchildren are a crown to the elderly, and the glory of children is their fathers.

verses.latin: Non decent stultum verba composita: multo magis principem os mendax.
verses.english: Foolish words are not appropriate for a fool, nor are lies suitable for a prince.

verses.latin: Lapis pretiosus gratia in oculis possessoris sui: quocumque se verterit, prudentiam capit.
verses.english: A precious stone is grace in the eyes of the owner. Wherever he turns, he finds wisdom.

verses.latin: Operiens delictum, quaerit amicitias: qui autem iterat sermonem, separat amicos.
verses.english: He who hides a transgression seeks friendship, but he who repeats a matter separates friends.

verses.latin: Plus proficit obiurgatio in sapientem, quam centum plagas in stultum.
verses.english: A reprimand works more on a wise man than a hundred lashes on a fool.

verses.latin: Homo malus quaerit solummodo scandalum: ideo angelus crudelis mittetur contra eum.
verses.english: An evil man seeks only to stir up trouble, therefore a cruel angel will be sent against him.

verses.latin: Melius est occurrere ursae raptis catulis, quam stulto in stultitia sua.
verses.english: It is better to encounter a bear robbed of her cubs, than a fool in his folly.

verses.latin: Qui reddit malum pro bono, non recedet malum de domo ejus.
verses.english: He who repays evil for good, evil will not depart from his house.

verses.latin: Qui emittit aquam, initium jurgii est: et antequam contineat, relinquit discordias.
verses.english: He who starts a quarrel is like one who lets out water. Stop before the strife begins.

verses.latin: Qui justificat impium, et qui condemnat justum, ambo abominabiles sunt apud Deum.
verses.english: He who justifies the wicked, and he who condemns the just, both are abominable to God.

verses.latin: Quare pretium habet stultus in manu sua, ut emat sapientiam, cum cor non habeat?
verses.english: Why does a fool have money in his hand to buy wisdom, when he has no heart for it?

verses.latin: Omni tempore diligit qui amicus est: et frater in angustiis comprobatur.
verses.english: A friend loves at all times, and a brother is proven in adversity.

verses.latin: Homo stultus plectrum dat manu, in conspectu amici sui: et non habet quod respondeat.
verses.english: A foolish man gives his hand as a pledge in the sight of his friend, but he has nothing to repay.

verses.latin: Qui diligit praevaricationem, amat jurgium: et qui exaltat ostium suum, quaerit ruinam.
verses.english: He who loves transgression loves contention, and he who exalts his gate seeks destruction.

verses.latin: Qui perversi cordis est, non inveniet bona: et qui vertit linguam, incidet in malum.
verses.english: He who is of a perverse heart finds no good, and he who uses a deceptive tongue falls into evil.

verses.latin: Qui generat stultum, habet tristitiam: et qui generat sibi fatuum, non gaudebit.
verses.english: He who begets a fool has sorrow, and the father of a foolish son will not rejoice.

verses.latin: Cor gaudens, bonam facit faciem: in tristitia mentis, conteritur spiritus.
verses.english: A cheerful heart makes a happy face, but sadness of mind crushes the spirit.

verses.latin: Impious accipit munera de sinu, ut pervertat semitas judicii.
verses.english: The wicked accepts a bribe from the cloak, to pervert the ways of justice.

verses.latin: In faciem stulti, sapientia ante oculos ejus: oculus fatui in finibus terrae.
verses.english: Wisdom is before the face of the wise, but the eyes of a fool are on the ends of the earth.

verses.latin: Filius sapiens, gaudium patris sui: et filius stultus, moeror matris suae.
verses.english: A wise son is the joy of his father, but a foolish son is the grief of his mother.

verses.latin: Non est bonum, punire justum: nec judicem innocuum, in plaga castigare.
verses.english: It is not good to punish the just, nor to strike the innocent, or a righteous judge.

verses.latin: Qui parcit verbis suis, doctus et prudens est: et vir pretiosi spiritus, habet scientiam.
verses.english: He who restrains his words is learned and prudent, and a man of a precious spirit has knowledge.

verses.latin: Stultus quoque, si tacuerit, sapiens reputabitur: et si compresserit labia sua, intelligens.
verses.english: Even a fool, when he holds his peace, is considered wise. If he closes his lips, he is considered prudent.

verses.latin: Cupidus, post desiderium, discordias provocat: qui se a negotiis immiscet, dolore replebitur.
verses.english: A selfish person will stir up quarrels after his own desires: whoever separates himself from good works will be filled with pain.

verses.latin: Non delectatur stultus prudentia, sed solum ut evulgata proferat.
verses.english: A fool takes no pleasure in understanding, but only in expressing his own opinions.

verses.latin: Cum venerit impius, contemnit, et cum venerit ignominiosus, exprobratio.
verses.english: When the wicked come, they are contemptuous, and when the dishonorable come, they heap scorn.

verses.latin: Aqua profunda, verba ex ore hominis: torrens profluens, fons sapientiæ.
verses.english: The words of a man's mouth are like deep waters; the source of wisdom, a flowing torrent.

verses.latin: Non est bonum accipere faciem impii, ut declines a judicio justi.
verses.english: It is not good to show partiality to the wicked, so as to undermine the judgment of the just.

verses.latin: Labia stulti miscent se cum lite, et os ejus advocat verbera.
verses.english: A fool's lips invite conflict, and his mouth calls for blows.

verses.latin: Os stulti, contritio ejus: et labia ejus, ruina animæ ejus.
verses.english: A fool's mouth is his ruin, and his lips are the snare of his soul.

verses.latin: Verba susurronis quasi plagarum, et illa descendunt in interiora ventris.
verses.english: The words of a whisperer are like wounds, and they go down into the innermost parts of the belly.

verses.latin: Qui rem remissus est in opere suo, frater est hominis qui se confodit.
verses.english: He who is remiss in his work is brother to him who destroys himself.

verses.latin: Turris fortissima nomen Domini: ad ipsum currit justus, et exaltabitur.
verses.english: The name of the Lord is a strong tower: the just run to it and are exalted.

verses.latin: Substantia divitis, urbs fortitudinis ejus: timor Domini, expellit impios.
verses.english: The rich man's wealth is his strong city: the fear of the Lord drives out the wicked.

verses.latin: Ante subversionem exaltatur cor hominis, et ante gloriam humiliatur spiritus.
verses.english: Before ruin, the heart of man is lifted up, and before glory, the spirit is humbled.

verses.latin: Qui ante audit, et respondit, stultus est, et confusione dignus.
verses.english: He who answers before he hears, is a fool and worthy of confusion.

verses.latin: Spiritus viri sustentabit infirmitatem suam: spiritum vero pusillanimem, quis poterit sustinere?
verses.english: A man's spirit will sustain his infirmity, but who can bear a broken spirit?

verses.latin: Cor prudentis possidebit scientiam, et auris sapientium quæret doctrinam.
verses.english: The heart of the prudent will possess knowledge, and the ear of the wise seeks doctrine.

verses.latin: Donum hominis dilatat viam ejus, et coram principibus spatium facit illi.
verses.english: A man's gift makes way for him, and brings him before the great.

verses.latin: Justus prior est in causa sua: veniet amicus ejus, et investigabit eum.
verses.english: The just man is first in his own cause: his friend comes and examines him.

verses.latin: Sortes cessare faciunt contentiones, et inter potentes separant.
verses.english: Lots stop disputes, and separate even the powerful.

verses.latin: Frater qui adjuvatur a fratre, quasi civitas firma: et judicia quasi seræ urbium.
verses.english: A brother helped by his brother is like a strong city, and judgements are like the bars of a city.

verses.latin: De fructu oris viri, saturabitur venter ejus, et proventus labiorum ejus, implebit eum.
verses.english: From the fruit of a man's mouth, his belly will be satisfied; with the produce of his lips he will be filled.

verses.latin: Mors et vita in manu linguæ: qui diligunt eam, comedent fructus ejus.
verses.english: Death and life are in the power of the tongue: those who love it will eat its fruit.

verses.latin: Qui invenit uxorem, invenit bonum, et hauriet jucunditatem a Domino.
verses.english: He who finds a wife finds a good thing, and will obtain favor from the Lord.

verses.latin: Cum obsecrationibus loquetur pauper, dives autem duriter respondebit.
verses.english: The poor man will speak with entreaties, but the rich man will answer roughly.

verses.latin: Homo plurimos amicos habens, in perniciem ruit: est autem amicus pertinaciter amans, supra fratrem nascitur.
verses.english: A man of many friends comes to ruin, but there is a friend who sticks closer than a brother.

verses.latin: Melius est pauper ambulans in simplicitate sua, quam dives in viis suis.
verses.english: It is better to be a poor man who walks in his integrity than a rich man who is deceitful.

verses.latin: Non est bonum esse sine doctrina animae, et qui festinus est pedibus offendit.
verses.english: It is not good for a soul to be without knowledge; haste makes men stumble.

verses.latin: Stultitia hominis subvertit vias suas, et contra Deum fervet cor ejus.
verses.english: A man's folly subverts his ways, and his heart rages against God.

verses.latin: Divitiæ addunt amicos plurimos; a paupere autem et hi qui sunt separantur.
verses.english: Riches bring many friends, but a poor man is separated even from his friend.

verses.latin: Testis falsus non erit impunitus, et qui mendacia loquitur, effugiet.
verses.english: A false witness will not go unpunished, and he who speaks lies will not escape.

verses.latin: Multi colunt personam potentis, et amici sunt dona dantis.
verses.english: Many court the favor of a great man, and everyone is a friend to a man who gives gifts.

verses.latin: Omnes fratres pauperis oderunt eum; insuper et amici procul recesserunt ab eo. Qui tantum verba sectatur, nihil habebit.
verses.english: All the brothers of the poor hate him; how much more do his friends stay far from him. He who merely pursues words will have nothing.

verses.latin: Qui autem intellectum habet, diligit animam suam; et qui conservat prudentiam, inveniet bona.
verses.english: He who gains understanding loves his own soul; he who keeps prudence will find good.

verses.latin: Testis falsus non erit impunitus, et qui profert verba mendacii, peribit.
verses.english: A false witness will not go unpunished, and he who pours forth words of lies will perish.

verses.latin: Delicatus non est ei stulto; nec convenit servo dominari principibus.
verses.english: Luxury does not suit a fool, nor does it suit a servant to rule princes.

verses.latin: Doctrina hominis retardat iram ejus, et gloria ejus est praeterire peccata.
verses.english: A man's discretion makes him slow to anger, and it is his glory to overlook a transgression.

verses.latin: Sicut rugitus leonis, ita et terror regis; qui vero irritat eum, peccat in animam suam.
verses.english: Like the roaring of a lion, so is the wrath of a king; but he who provokes him sins against his own soul.

verses.latin: Foeda est stultitia hominis, ad perditionem ejus; et cor hominis praecedit eum ad malum.
verses.english: A man's folly ruins his own way, and his heart rages against God.

verses.latin: Paupertas impellit hominem ad malum; dat operam dives, et non augetur.
verses.english: Poverty impels a man to ruin; a rich man labors, and does not increase.

verses.latin: Filius nequam contristat patrem, et lacrimas matris exhaurit.
verses.english: A wicked son grieves his father and drains the tears of his mother.

verses.latin: Non est bonum damnare justum judicio, nec flagellare principes in judicio.
verses.english: It is not good to condemn the just in judgment, nor to scourge the nobles.

verses.latin: Qui parcit virgae, odit filium suum; qui autem diligit eum, instat erudiendo.
verses.english: He who spares the rod hates his son, but he who loves him disciplines him diligently.

verses.latin: Qui justus est in modico, et in magno justus est; et qui iniquus est in modico, et in magno iniquus est.
verses.english: He who is just in a small thing is just also in a great thing; and he who is unjust in a small thing is unjust also in a great thing.

verses.latin: Divitiæ non proderunt in die irae; justitia vero liberabit a morte.
verses.english: Riches will not profit in the day of wrath, but justice delivers from death.

verses.latin: Qui custodit mendacium, odibilis est; et vir mendax, opprobrium est.
verses.english: He who guards falsehood is hateful, and a man of lies is an abomination.

verses.latin: Qui nequam est, ad malum properat; et vir malus, desiderat pedem.
verses.english: He who is wicked hastens to do evil, and a wicked man desires to fall.

verses.latin: Desiderium hominis misericordia ejus; et melior est pauper quam mendax.
verses.english: A man's desire is his mercy, and a poor man is better than a liar.

verses.latin: Timor Domini ad vitam; et in plenitudine ejus demorabitur homo.
verses.english: The fear of the Lord leads to life, and in its fullness, a man will abide.

verses.latin: Inserit piger manum suam in sinu, et non adfert eam ad os suum.
verses.english: The slothful puts his hand in his bosom, and will not bring it to his mouth.

verses.latin: Percusso stulto, sapientior erit; et arguento prudentem, addetur scientia.
verses.english: Strike a fool, and he will become wiser; rebuke a wise man, and knowledge will be added to him.

verses.latin: Qui contristat patrem, et qui fugat matrem, ignominiosus est et infelix.
verses.english: He who wrongs his father and chases away his mother is a disgraceful and unhappy man.

verses.latin: Cesse, fili, audire doctrinam, et errare a verbis scientiae.
verses.english: Stop, son, from hearing instruction and straying from the words of knowledge.

verses.latin: Testis iniquus irridet judicium, et os impiorum degluttit iniquitatem.
verses.english: An unjust witness scoffs at judgment, and the mouth of the wicked devours iniquity.

verses.latin: Parata sunt stultis judicia, et percussiones corporibus imprudentium.
verses.english: Judgments are ready for fools, and beatings for the backs of the imprudent.

verses.latin: Vinum inlusor est, tumultuosus  cibus ebrietas: qui in his delectatur, non erit sapiens.
verses.english: Drinking wine is a game for fools. Drunkenness brings rowdy behavior. Whoever enjoys it will not become wise.

verses.latin: Terror regis quasi rugitus leonis: qui ad iracundiam eum provocat, peccat in animam suam.
verses.english: The king's anger is like a lion's roar. Whoever provokes him sins against their own soul.

verses.latin: Honoris est homini desinere a contentionibus: omnis autem stultus miscetur jurgiis.
verses.english: It is honorable to avoid strife, but every fool is quick to start arguments.

verses.latin: Propter frigus piger arare noluit: mendicabit ergo aestate, et non dabitur ei.
verses.english: The lazy person will not plow because of the cold. Therefore, they will beg in summer, but will not receive anything.

verses.latin: Sicut aqua, sic cor hominis in cogitationibus: sapiens autem vir requiret illud.
verses.english: The heart of a man is like water, full of changing thoughts, but a wise man will draw them out.

verses.latin: Multi homines vocantur misericordes: virum autem fidelem quis inveniet?
verses.english: Many people claim to be kind, but who can find a trustworthy person?

verses.latin: Justus qui in simplicitate sua ambulat: relictis post se filiis suis.
verses.english: The just man walks with integrity, leaving his children a good legacy.

verses.latin: Rex sedens in solio judicii, dissipat omne malum intuitu suo.
verses.english: A king sitting on his throne judges and separates good from evil with his insight.

verses.latin: Quis potest dicere: Mundum est cor meum, purus sum a peccato meo?
verses.english: Who can say, “I have kept my heart pure; I am cleansed from sin”?

verses.latin: Bina mensura et bina sarcina, abominatio est apud Deum.
verses.english: False weights and false measures are an abomination to God.

verses.latin: Puer etiam in actibus suis ostendit si munda et recta sint opera ejus.
verses.english: Even a child is known by their actions, by whether their deeds are pure and upright.

verses.latin: Aurim et gemmam qui diligit, non habebit requiem: sed qui calumniam detestatur, longe erit a turpitudine.
verses.english: Whoever loves gold and jewels will not have rest, but whoever hates slander will stay far from shame.

verses.latin: Qui custodit os suum, custodit animam suam: qui autem inconsideratus est in lingua, incurret ruinam.
verses.english: He who guards his mouth guards his life, but he who speaks carelessly brings ruin upon himself.

verses.latin: Dicit piger: Leo est foris, interficiar in mediis plateis.
verses.english: The lazy man says, “There is a lion outside, I will be killed in the middle of the streets.”

verses.latin: Os impiorum venenum est: lingua eorum sicut gladius.
verses.english: The mouths of the wicked are full of poison, and their tongues are like swords.

verses.latin: Qui credit stulto, inimicus est sui: et qui detestatur correptiones, stultus est.
verses.english: Whoever trusts a fool is an enemy of themselves, and whoever hates correction is a fool.

verses.latin: Qui malum cogitat, fraudis vocabitur: et qui concupiscit gloriam, fugiet.
verses.english: Whoever plans evil will be called a schemer, and whoever desires fame will flee from it.

verses.latin: Justus pro impio, et impius pro justo: uterque abominabilis est apud Deum.
verses.english: The righteous person for the wicked, and the wicked person for the righteous: both are abominable to God.

verses.latin: Melius est habitare in terra deserta, quam cum muliere rixosa et iracunda.
verses.english: It is better to dwell in a desert land than with a quarrelsome and angry woman.

verses.latin: Thesaurus desiderabilis, et oleum in habitaculo sapientis: stultus autem homo dissipabit illud.
verses.english: A desirable treasure and oil are in the dwelling of the wise, but a foolish man squanders them.

verses.latin: Qui sequitur justitiam et misericordiam, inveniet vitam, justitiam, et gloriam.
verses.english: Whoever pursues righteousness and mercy will find life, righteousness, and honor.

verses.latin: Oppidum fortium ascendit sapiens: et destruet robur fiducia ejus.
verses.english: A wise man ascends the city of the mighty and destroys the strength in which they trust.

verses.latin: Qui custodit os suum et linguam suam, custodit ab angustiis animam suam.
verses.english: He who guards his mouth and his tongue keeps himself from trouble.

verses.latin: Superbus et arrogans vocatur stultus.
verses.english: The proud and arrogant person is called a fool.

verses.latin: Desideria piger interficiunt eum: noluit enim operari manibus suis.
verses.english: The desires of the lazy person kill them, for they do not want to work with their own hands.

verses.latin: Tota die concupiscit et cupit: justus autem dat et non parcet.
verses.english: All day, the wicked desires and covets, but the righteous gives generously and does not hold back.

verses.latin: Victima impiorum abominabilis est: eo quod ex malitia offertur.
verses.english: The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination because it is offered with evil intent.

verses.latin: Testis mendax peribit: vir autem audiens loquetur in aeternum.
verses.english: A lying witness will perish, but the man who listens will speak forever.

verses.latin: Impius inultus ludit faciem: justus autem diriget viam suam.
verses.english: A wicked man hardens his face; but as for the just, he directs his way.

verses.latin: Non est sapientia, non est prudentia, non est consilium contra Deum.
verses.english: There is no wisdom, no understanding, no counsel against God.

verses.latin: Equus paratur in die belli: Dominus autem est qui tribuit salutem.
verses.english: A horse is prepared for the day of battle, but the Lord grants salvation.

verses.latin: Sicut divisio aquarum, ita cor regis in manu Dei: quocumque voluerit, inclinabit illud.
verses.english: Like streams of water, the heart of the king is in God's hand; He directs it as He wishes.

verses.latin: Omnis via viri recta sibi videtur: probator autem cordium est Dominus.
verses.english: A man's way seems right to him, but the Lord examines hearts.

verses.latin: Facere misericordiam et judicium magis placet Domino quam victimae.
verses.english: To do what is right and just is more pleasing to the Lord than sacrifices.

verses.latin: Altitudine oculorum et tumente corde, non est quod placeat Deo.
verses.english: Haughty eyes and a proud heart—these things displease God.

verses.latin: Cogitationes cordis diligentis, quasi aqua; et judicium et veritas probantur in viro impio.
verses.english: The thoughts of the diligent are like a stream of water; but judgment and truth are found in the wicked man.

verses.latin: Opera impiorum insidiantur animabus: qui autem custodiunt vias suas, diliguntur.
verses.english: The works of the wicked ambush souls; but those who guard their ways are loved.

verses.latin: Expeditio impiorum cito peribit: seminaverit enim iniquitatem et metet eam.
verses.english: The violence of the wicked will quickly consume them, for they sow iniquity and reap it.

verses.latin: Cor sapiens suscipiet mandata: et stultus corripitur a lingua.
verses.english: The wise heart receives commands, while the fool is rebuked by the tongue.

verses.latin: Qui celat delictum, quaerit amicitias: qui autem objurgat rem, separabit amicum.
verses.english: He who hides his offense seeks friendship; but he who rebukes the matter separates a friend.

verses.latin: Plus proficit correptio apud intelligentem, quam centum plagas stulto.
verses.english: A rebuke strikes deeper into the discerning than a hundred blows into a fool.

verses.latin: Vir malus quaerit solummodo iniquitatem: propterea angelus malus mittetur contra eum.
verses.english: An evil man seeks only wickedness, therefore a wicked angel will be sent against him.

verses.latin: Vasa pretiosa et oleum in habitaculo justi: et insipiens dissipabit ea.
verses.english: Precious things and oil are in the dwelling of the just, but a foolish man will destroy them.

verses.latin: Qui claudit aurem suam ad clamorem pauperis, et ipse clamabit, et non exaudietur.
verses.english: He who closes his ear to the cry of the poor will also cry out and not be heard.

verses.latin: Munus in abscondito mitigat iras: et donum in sinu, indignationem vehementem.
verses.english: A gift in secret pacifies anger, and a present in the bosom, strong wrath.

verses.latin: Gaudium justo, facere judicium: et pavor his qui operantur iniquitatem.
verses.english: It is a joy to the just to do justice, but terror to those who practice iniquity.

verses.latin: Homo qui errat a via doctrinae, in coetu gigantum requiescet.
verses.english: The man who wanders from the way of instruction will remain in the company of giants.

verses.latin: Vir indigens dilectionem, inops erit: qui amat vinum et pinguia, non ditabitur.
verses.english: He who loves pleasure will be in need; he who loves wine and luxury will not be rich.

verses.latin: Redemptio pro justo, est impius: et pro recto, qui agit iniquitatem.
verses.english: The wicked man is a ransom for the just, and the one who acts iniquity is a ransom for the upright.

verses.latin: Melius est habitare in terra deserta, quam cum muliere rixosa et iracunda.
verses.english: It is better to dwell in the wilderness, than with a contentious and angry woman.

verses.latin: Thesaurus desiderabilis et oleum in habitaculo sapientis: et stultus vir dissipabit illud.
verses.english: There is a desirable treasure and oil in the dwelling of the wise, but the foolish man will destroy it.

verses.latin: Qui sequitur justitiam et misericordiam, inveniet vitam, justitiam et gloriam.
verses.english: He who pursues justice and mercy finds life, justice, and glory.

verses.latin: Sapiens ascendit urbem fortium, et destruet robur fiducia illius.
verses.english: A wise man attacks a city of the mighty and will destroy the strength of its confidence.

verses.latin: Qui custodit os suum et linguam suam, custodit a tribulationibus animam suam.
verses.english: He who guards his mouth and his tongue guards his soul from tribulations.

verses.latin: Superbus et arrogans, linguae nomen, superbiae, est quod agit.
verses.english: Proud and arrogant is the one who speaks a name for pride.

verses.latin: Desideria pigrorum occidunt eos: nolunt enim facere quidquam.
verses.english: The desires of the lazy kill them, for they do not want to do anything.

verses.latin: Tota die concupiscit avarus: qui autem dat, tribuet, et non auferetur.
verses.english: The greedy man covets all day long, but he who gives, will share, and will not be taken away from.

verses.latin: Victima impiorum abominabilis est: eo quod offertur ex impietate.
verses.english: The sacrifice of the wicked is abominable, because it is offered in wickedness.

verses.latin: Testis mendax peribit: vir autem audiens loquetur in aeternum.
verses.english: A lying witness will perish, but a man who hears speaks eternally.

verses.latin: Impudens ostendit faciem suam: et stultus erubescit.
verses.english: A wicked man hardens his face, but the fool blushes.

verses.latin: Melius est timere, et non sapere, quam timere, et in via stulta esse.
verses.english: It is better to fear and not know, than to fear and be on a foolish path.

verses.latin: Paratur equus ad diem belli: Domini autem est victoria.
verses.english: The horse is prepared for the day of battle, but victory belongs to the Lord.

verses.latin: Melior est nomen bonum quam divitiae multae: super gratiam argentum et aurum.
verses.english: It is better to have a good name than riches, because grace is better than silver or gold.

verses.latin: Dives et pauper obviaverunt sibi: utriusque operator est Dominus.
verses.english: The rich and the poor have met each other, and the Lord made them both.

verses.latin: Astutus videt malum, et cavet: parvuli transeunt, et puniuntur.
verses.english: A prudent man sees the evil and hides himself, but the simple pass on and suffer.

verses.latin: Merces humilitatis et timoris Domini, divitiae et gloria et vita.
verses.english: The reward of humility and the fear of the Lord is riches and glory and life.

verses.latin: Spinae et laquei in via perversi: qui custodit animam suam, procul recedat ab eis.
verses.english: Thorns and snares are in the way of the perverse, and he who keeps his soul will withdraw from them.

verses.latin: Instrux puerum in via sua, et cum senuerit, non recedet ab ea.
verses.english: Train up a child in the way he should go; and when he is old, he will not depart from it.

verses.latin: Dives pauperibus dominabitur: et qui mutuat, servus est fenerantis.
verses.english: The rich shall have dominion over the poor, and the borrower is servant to the lender.

verses.latin: Qui seminat iniquitatem, metet mala: et virga furoris sui consumpmabitur.
verses.english: He who sows iniquity shall reap evils, and with the rod of his wrath he shall be consumed.

verses.latin: Qui oculo malus est, irritat ad divitias: et ignorat quod superveniant sibi egestas.
verses.english: He who is generous will be blessed, for he gives of his bread to the poor.

verses.latin: Ejice derisorem, et exibit cum eo jurgium, et cessabit causa et contumelia.
verses.english: Cast out the mocker, and contention will go out with him, and strife and reproach shall cease.

verses.latin: Qui diligit cordis munditiam, propter gratiam labiorum suorum, habebit amicum regem.
verses.english: He who loves cleanness of heart, for the grace of his lips, will have the king for his friend.

verses.latin: Oculi Domini custodiunt scientiam: et subvertent verba iniqui.
verses.english: The eyes of the Lord preserve knowledge, and He will overthrow the words of the wicked.

verses.latin: Dicit piger: Leo est foris: interficiar in mediis plateis.
verses.english: The sluggard says: “There is a lion outside, and I will be slain in the midst of the streets.”

verses.latin: Fovea profunda os alienae: cui iratus est Dominus, incidet in eam.
verses.english: A deep pit is the mouth of a prostitute, and he whom the Lord hates will fall into it.

verses.latin: Stultitia innata est in corde pueri, et virga disciplinae expellit eam.
verses.english: Foolishness is bound up in the heart of a child, but the rod of discipline will drive it away from him.

verses.latin: Qui ditatur, pauperibus dolet: et qui donat divitias, indiget.
verses.english: He who oppresses the poor will increase his riches, and he who gives to the rich will want.

verses.latin: Inclina aurem tuam, et audi verba sapientium: et appone cor tuum ad doctrinam meam.
verses.english: Incline your ear, and hear the words of the wise, and apply your heart to my doctrine.

verses.latin: Dulce enim erit si servaveris ea in ventre tuo: et componentur simul in labiis tuis.
verses.english: For it will be pleasant if you keep these things in your heart, and they shall be spoken together on your lips.

verses.latin: Ut sit in Domino fiducia tua: ideo ostendi tibi hodie.
verses.english: That your trust may be in the Lord, I have shown these things to you today.

verses.latin: Ecce, descripsi ea tibi tripliciter in cogitationibus et scientia,
verses.english: Behold, I have described these things to you three times in thoughts and knowledge,

verses.latin: ut ostenderem tibi veritatem, et responsa veritatis, et ut referas illis qui te miserunt.
verses.english: so that I might show you the truth, and the answers of truth, and that you might answer those who sent you.

verses.latin: Ne mordeas panem cum eo qui malus est oculo: nec appetas escas ejus.
verses.english: Do not bite the bread with a man of an evil eye, nor desire his delicacies.

verses.latin: Quoniam qualis est in cogitationibus suis, talis est: comedens et bibens, dicit tibi: Comede et bibe: et cor ejus non est tecum.
verses.english: For such as he is in his thoughts, so is he: he says to you, “Eat and drink,” but his heart is not with you.

verses.latin: Mors illius in vase ejus: et sub pedibus illius, infernus.
verses.english: Death is in his vessel, and hell is under his feet.

verses.latin: Stultitia innata est in corde pueri: propter hoc, virga corrige eum.
verses.english: Foolishness is bound up in the heart of a child, therefore, correct him with the rod.

verses.latin: Qui contristat patrem, et fugat matrem, ignominiosus est et infelix.
verses.english: He who grieves his father, and drives away his mother, is shameful and unhappy.

verses.latin: Fili, cessa audire doctrinam, et errare a verbis scientiae.
verses.english: My son, cease to hear instruction, and to err from the words of knowledge.

verses.latin: Testis iniquus deridet judicium: et os impiorum deglutit iniquitatem.
verses.english: A wicked witness scoffs at judgment, and the mouth of the wicked devours iniquity.

verses.latin: Parata sunt derisoribus judicia, et mallei percutientes stultorum corpus.
verses.english: Judgments are prepared for mockers, and the stripes for the backs of fools.

verses.latin: Cum sederis ad mensam cum principe, attende diligenter quae posita sunt ante te.
verses.english: When you dine with a ruler, pay careful attention to what is set before you.

verses.latin: Et pone cultellum in gutture tuo, si es homo avarus.
verses.english: If you are prone to greed, put a knife to your throat.

verses.latin: Noli concupiscere cibos ejus, in quibus est panis mortis.
verses.english: Do not crave his delicacies, which contain the bread of death.

verses.latin: Noli laborare ad divitias: sed requiesce a cogitatione tua.
verses.english: Do not work to become rich. Keep your focus on other things.

verses.latin: Cum fixeris oculos tuos in illas, statim volabunt: et avolant per viam quasi aquila in caelum.
verses.english: When you set your eyes on riches, they vanish instantly. They fly away like an eagle in the sky.

verses.latin: Noli comedere panem cum homine invido, et noli concupiscere cibos ejus:
verses.english: Do not eat the bread of a stingy man, and do not crave his delicacies.

verses.latin: quoniam qualis est cogitatio ejus in anima sua, talis est ipse: comedens et bibens, dicet tibi: Comede et bibe: sed cor ejus non est tecum.
verses.english: For he is what he thinks in his soul. He will tell you, as he eats and drinks, “Eat and drink.” But his heart is not with you.

verses.latin: Victualia quae comederas, evomes, et perdes verba tua dulcia.
verses.english: You will vomit the food you ate, and lose your sweet words.

verses.latin: In auribus insipientis ne loquaris, qui despicit disciplinam sermonis tui.
verses.english: Do not speak in the ears of a fool, for he despises the discipline of your speech.

verses.latin: Ne transferas terminos antiquos, et in agrum pupillorum ne introeas.
verses.english: Do not move the ancient boundary markers, nor enter the fields of orphans.

verses.latin: Quia propinquior est qui vindicabit illos, et ipse defendet causam eorum.
verses.english: For their defender is near, and He will defend their cause.

verses.latin: Aplica ad disciplinam cor tuum, et aures tuas ad verba scientiae.
verses.english: Apply your heart to discipline, and your ears to the words of knowledge.

verses.latin: Ne subtrahas a puero disciplinam: quia si percusseris eum virga, non morietur.
verses.english: Do not withhold discipline from a child; if you strike him with the rod, he will not die.

verses.latin: Tu virga percuties eum, et animam ejus de inferno liberabis.
verses.english: You will strike him with the rod, and deliver his soul from hell.

verses.latin: Fili mi, si sapiens fuerit cor tuum, gaudebit et cor meum;
verses.english: My son, if your heart is wise, my heart will also rejoice.

verses.latin: et exsultabunt renes mei, cum locuta fuerint labia tua recta.
verses.english: And my inner self will rejoice when your lips speak what is right.

verses.latin: Non aemuletur cor tuum peccatores: sed in timore Dei esto tota die.
verses.english: Do not let your heart envy sinners, but live in the fear of God all day.

verses.latin: Quia habet spei in novissimo suo: et spes tua non peribit.
verses.english: For there is hope in the end; your hope will not perish.

verses.latin: Audi, fili mi, et esto sapiens, et dirige in via cor tuum.
verses.english: Listen, my son, and be wise, and direct your heart on the way.

verses.latin: Noli esse in conviviis potantium, neque in comessationibus eorum qui pecunias consumunt.
verses.english: Do not be with those who drink too much wine, nor with gluttons.

verses.latin: Quoniam potores et comessatores ad paupertatem rediguntur: et dormitio vestit pannos.
verses.english: For drunkards and gluttons are reduced to poverty, and drowsiness clothes a man in rags.

verses.latin: Audi filium meum, et non contemnas patrem tuum: cum senex fuerit mater tua, ne spernas eam.
verses.english: Listen to your father who gave you life and do not despise him; and when your mother is old, do not despise her.

verses.latin: Veritatem adquire, et noli vendere: et sapientiam, et doctrinam, et prudentiam.
verses.english: Acquire truth, and do not sell it; also acquire wisdom, instruction, and understanding.

verses.latin: Pater justi gaudebit, et qui genuit sapientem, laetabitur in eo.
verses.english: The father of the just man will rejoice, and he who has begotten a wise son will be glad in him.

verses.latin: Gaudebit pater tuus et mater tua, et exsultabit quae genuit te.
verses.english: Your father and your mother will rejoice, and she who bore you will be glad.

verses.latin: Fili mi, da mi cor tuum, et oculi tui vias meas custodiant.
verses.english: My son, give me your heart, and let your eyes keep my ways.

verses.latin: Prostituta enim fovea profunda est: et angustia aliena illius.
verses.english: For a harlot is a deep pit, and a strange woman is a narrow pit.

verses.latin: Ista quoque insidiatur quasi latro: et quos non novit multiplicat praevaricationes.
verses.english: She lies in wait as a robber does, and she increases the number of those who transgress.

verses.latin: Cui vae? cui pater? cui rixae? cui foveae? cui sine causa vulnera? cui oculos suffusio?
verses.english: Who suffers? Who has sorrow? Who has contentions? Who has complaints? Who has wounds without cause? Who has bloodshot eyes?

verses.latin: Nonne his qui morantur in vino, et student calicibus ad miscendam?
verses.english: Are these not the ones who linger long over wine and go to taste mixed drinks?

verses.latin: Ne intuearis vinum, quando flavescit, cum dederit in vitro colorem suum: ingreditur blande, sed in novissimo mordet ut coluber, et sicut regulus venena irrogat.
verses.english: Do not look at the wine when it is red, when it gives its color in the glass: it goes down smoothly, but in the end it bites like a serpent and stings like a viper.

verses.latin: Oculi tui videbunt extraneas, et cor tuum loquetur perversa.
verses.english: Your eyes will see strange women, and your heart will speak perverse things.

verses.latin: Et eris sicut dormiens in medio maris, et quasi gubernator in tempestate jacens.
verses.english: You will be like one who sleeps in the midst of the sea, and like a pilot lying on the mast during a storm.

verses.latin: Et dicies: Verberaverunt me, sed non dolui: traxerunt me, et ego non sensi: quando evigilabo, et rursum vinum inveniam?
verses.english: And you will say, “They struck me, but I did not hurt; they dragged me, but I did not feel it; when shall I awake, and find wine again?”

verses.latin: Noli æmulari viros malos, nec cupias esse cum eis:
verses.english: Don’t be jealous of wicked men, nor desire to be with them.

verses.latin: quia cor eorum de meditatione rapinarum cogitat, et lingua eorum fraudes loquitur.
verses.english: Because their hearts are always plotting violence, and their words are full of deceit.

verses.latin: In sapientia domus ædificabitur, et prudentia firmabitur.
verses.english: By wisdom, a household is built. By good judgment, it is made strong.

verses.latin: In scientia replebuntur cellaria omni substantia pretiosa et pulcherrima.
verses.english: By understanding, the storerooms are filled with precious and beautiful treasures.

verses.latin: Vir sapiens fortis est, et vir doctus robustus et validus.
verses.english: A wise man is strong, and a man of knowledge is sturdy and powerful.

verses.latin: quia cum consilia facis, geras bellum contra te, et in multitudine consiliariorum salus.
verses.english: Because when you make plans, it is like waging war against yourself. In the multitude of those you counsel, there is safety.

verses.latin: Stulta nimis est alta sapientia in ore impii: ideo in porta non aperiet os suum.
verses.english: Wisdom is too high for a fool. Therefore, he will not open his mouth in the gate.

verses.latin: Qui cogitat facere malum, stultus vocabitur.
verses.english: He who plots to do evil will be called a fool.

verses.latin: Cogitatio stulti peccatum est, et detractor abominabilis est hominibus.
verses.english: The thought of a fool is sin, and the scorner is an abomination to men.

verses.latin: Si lassus fueris in die angustiæ, imminuetur fortitudo tua.
verses.english: If you are weak in the day of distress, your strength will be diminished.

verses.latin: Erue eos qui ducuntur ad mortem, et qui trahuntur ad interitum, liberare ne cesses.
verses.english: Deliver those who are led to death, and do not hesitate to free those who are being dragged to destruction.

verses.latin: Si dixeris: Non est mihi ista facultas: ille qui corda ponderat, ipse novit: et qui conservat animas, ipse redribuit homini juxta opera sua.
verses.english: If you say, “I did not know what to do,” He who weighs the hearts knows. He who guards the souls knows, and He will repay a man according to his deeds.

verses.latin: Comede, fili mi, mel, quia bonum est, et favum mellis dulce palato tuo.
verses.english: Eat honey, my son, for it is good, and the honeycomb is sweet to your palate.

verses.latin: Sic et scientia sapientiæ animæ tuæ: quam cum inveneris, habebis spem, et in novissimo tua non peribis.
verses.english: So, too, is the knowledge of wisdom to your soul. When you find it, you will have hope, and you will not perish in the end.

verses.latin: Ne insidieris, vir impie, contra habitaculum justi, neque vastes locum ejus.
verses.english: Do not lie in wait, you wicked man, against the dwelling of the just, nor destroy his place.

verses.latin: septies enim cadet justus, et resurget: impii autem corruent in malum.
verses.english: For the just man will fall seven times, and he will rise again. But the wicked will fall into evil.

verses.latin: Cum ceciderit inimicus tuus, ne gaudeas, et in ruina ejus non exultet cor tuum:
verses.english: When your enemy falls, do not rejoice. Let your heart not exult in his ruin.

verses.latin: ne forte videat Dominus, et displiceat ei, et auferat iram suam a te.
verses.english: Lest perhaps the Lord see and be displeased, and remove his anger from you.

verses.latin: Ne æmuleris homines malos, neque cupias esse cum impiis:
verses.english: Do not be jealous of evil men, nor desire to be with the wicked.

verses.latin: quia non habebunt malitiosi in posteritatem, et lucerna impiorum extinguetur.
verses.english: Because the wicked will not have any posterity, and the lamp of the wicked will be extinguished.

verses.latin: Time Dominum, fili mi, et regem: et cum his qui novant, ne te immiscueris:
verses.english: Fear the Lord, my son, and the king. And do not associate with those who are given to change.

verses.latin: quia subito veniet perditio eorum, et ruinam utriusque quis novit?
verses.english: Because their destruction will come suddenly, and who knows the ruin of both?

verses.latin: Et hæc quoque ad sapientes. Judicare personam in judicio non est bonum.
verses.english: Also, these things belong to the wise. It is not good to show partiality in judgment.

verses.latin: Qui dicit impio: Justus es, maledictus erit a populis, et blasphemabunt eum nationes.
verses.english: He who says to the wicked, “You are just,” will be cursed by the people, and the nations will blaspheme him.

verses.latin: eos autem qui arguerint eum, delectabit, et veniet super illos benedictio boni.
verses.english: But those who rebuke him will be delighted, and the blessing of the good will come upon them.

verses.latin: Labia osculabitur qui recta responsa dat.
verses.english: The one who gives a right answer will kiss the lips.

verses.latin: Præpara foris opus tuum, et diligenter exerce illud in agro: et deinde ædificabis domum tuam.
verses.english: Prepare your work outside, and diligently practice it in the field. And then you will build your house.

verses.latin: Noli esse testis frustra contra proximum tuum: aut decipias labiis tuis.
verses.english: Do not be a false witness against your neighbor, or deceive with your lips.

verses.latin: Ne dicas: Quod fecit mihi, faciam illi: reddam unicuique secundum opera sua.
verses.english: Do not say, “I will do to him as he has done to me; I will repay each one according to his works.”

verses.latin: Per agrum hominis pigri transivi, et per vineam viri stulti:
verses.english: I passed through the field of a lazy man and through the vineyard of a foolish man.

verses.latin: et ecce, omnia repleverantur urticis, et operuerant superficiem ejus spinæ, et maceria lapidum diruta erat.
verses.english: And behold, everything was filled with nettles, and thorns covered its surface, and the stone wall was broken down.

verses.latin: Quod vidi, posui in corde meo: et ex hoc didici doctrinam.
verses.english: When I saw this, I put it in my heart, and from this, I learned a lesson.

verses.latin: Pauca dormiens, paululum dormitans, pauxillum manibus conserens ut quiescas:
verses.english: A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to rest.

verses.latin: et veniet quasi viator egestas tua, et mendicitas tua quasi vir armatus.
verses.english: And poverty will come upon you like a traveler, and your need like an armed man.

verses.latin: Haec quoque parabolae Salomonis, quas transtulerunt viri Ezechiae regis Juda.
verses.english: These are also the proverbs of Solomon, which the men of Hezekiah, king of Judah, translated.

verses.latin: Gloria Dei celare verbum; et gloria regum investigare verbum.
verses.english: It is the glory of God to conceal a thing; and the glory of kings is to investigate it.

verses.latin: Caelum altius terrae, et cor regum inscrutabile.
verses.english: The sky is higher than the earth, and the heart of kings is unfathomable.

verses.latin: Aufer robiginem de argento, et exibit vas purissimum.
verses.english: Take away the rust from silver, and there will come forth a most pure vessel.

verses.latin: Aufer impietatem de facie regis, et firmabitur justitia throni ejus.
verses.english: Remove wickedness from before the king, and his throne will be established in justice.

verses.latin: Ne glorieris coram principe, et noli stare in loco impiorum.
verses.english: Do not boast before the prince, and do not stand in the place of the wicked.

verses.latin: Melius est enim, ut dicatur tibi: Ascende huc, quam ut humilieris coram principe.
verses.english: For it is better that it be said to you: "Come up here," than that you should be humbled before the prince.

verses.latin: Quod viderunt oculi tui, ne proferas cito in judicio: ne postea emendare debeas, cum malum inveneris.
verses.english: What your eyes have seen, do not bring forth quickly in judgment, lest afterward you should have to amend it, when you have found evil.

verses.latin: Causa tua cum proximo tuo, disserito cum eo: et aliorum secretum ne reveles.
verses.english: Debate your case with your neighbor, and speak with him: but do not reveal the secret of another.

verses.latin: Ne forte audiat, et confundaris, et non possis tollere opprobrium tuum.
verses.english: Lest he hear it and be ashamed, and you will not be able to remove your disgrace.

verses.latin: Pomum aureum in scutella argentea, loquela bona in tempore suo.
verses.english: Like golden apples in silver settings is a word spoken in due season.

verses.latin: Anima refrigerans in die frigoris, aqua frigida sitienti, ita est bona nuntiatio de terra longinqua.
verses.english: As a cooling soul on a day of cold, as cold water to the thirsty, so is good news from a far country.

verses.latin: Fons turbatus, et vena corrupta, justus cadens coram impio.
verses.english: A troubled fountain, and a corrupted spring, a just man falling before the wicked.

verses.latin: Qui aufert pallium de die frigoris, et qui quasi aceto nitrum, qui cantat carmina cordi, est.
verses.english: He who takes away a garment in the day of cold, and he who is like vinegar on nitre, who sings songs to a heart, is.

verses.latin: Si esurierit inimicus tuus, ciba eum: si sitierit, da ei potum. Hoc enim faciens, carbones ignis congeres super caput ejus.
verses.english: If your enemy is hungry, feed him: if he is thirsty, give him drink. For by so doing, you will heap coals of fire upon his head.

verses.latin: Ventus aquilo dissipat pluvias: facies tristis linguam detrahentem.
verses.english: The north wind drives away the rains: so does a frowning face a backbiting tongue.

verses.latin: Melius est habitare in angulo tecti, quam cum muliere litigiosa et in domo communi.
verses.english: It is better to dwell in a corner of the roof, than with a contentious woman in a common house.

verses.latin: Aqua frigida sitienti, et nuntius bonus de terra longinqua.
verses.english: As cold water to a thirsty soul, and as good news from a far country.

verses.latin: Fons turbatus, et vena corrupta, justus cadens coram impio.
verses.english: A troubled fountain, and a corrupted spring, a just man falling before the wicked.

verses.latin: Comedere mel multum, non est bonum: et qui gravis est gloriae, opprimetur a gloria.
verses.english: To eat too much honey is not good: and he who is burdened by glory, will be oppressed by glory.

verses.latin: Quasi urbs pervia, et absque murorum ambitu, ita vir qui non potest frenare spiritum suum.
verses.english: As a city open to attack, and without walls, so is a man who cannot restrain his spirit.

verses.latin: Quasi stultus mittit sagittam et mortiferam, sic vir qui loquitur contra amicum fraudulenter.
verses.english: Like a fool who shoots an arrow and deadly ones, so is the man who speaks against his friend deceptively.

verses.latin: Labia inimici foventur in dolis: sed in medio ejus detrahitur.
verses.english: The lips of an enemy are smoothed with deceit: but in his heart he nurses a plot.

verses.latin: Qui odit, dissimulat in labiis suis, et in corde suo concipit dolos.
verses.english: He who hates, dissembles with his lips, and in his heart conceives deceit.

verses.latin: Cum laeta voce ne credideris ei, quoniam septem nequitiae sunt in corde ejus.
verses.english: When he speaks with a cheerful voice, do not believe him: for there are seven abominations in his heart.

verses.latin: Qui operit odium fraude, revelabitur malitia ejus in concilio.
verses.english: He who covers hatred with deceit, his wickedness will be revealed in the assembly.

verses.latin: Qui fodit foveam, incidet in eam: et qui volvit lapidem, revertetur ad eum.
verses.english: He who digs a pit will fall into it: and he who rolls a stone, it will return upon him.

verses.latin: Lingua fallax odium mentitur: et os lubricum operit malitias.
verses.english: A lying tongue hates the truth: and a flattering mouth works ruin.

verses.latin: Sicut nix in æstate, et pluvia in messe, sic non convenit stulto gloria.
verses.english: Like snow in the summer and rain during the harvest, glory isn’t fitting for the fool.

verses.latin: Sicut avis ad volandum, et passer ad volandum, sic maledictio irrita in domo alterius.
verses.english: Like a bird flying away or a sparrow soaring, a curse without reason doesn’t land.

verses.latin: Flagellum equo, et frænum asino, et virga dorso stultorum.
verses.english: A whip for a horse, a bridle for a donkey, and a rod for the back of the fools.

verses.latin: Ne respondeas stulto juxta stultitiam suam, ne efficiaris ei similis.
verses.english: Don't answer a fool according to his folly, lest you become like him.

verses.latin: Responde stulto juxta stultitiam suam, ne sibi sapiens esse videatur.
verses.english: Answer a fool according to his folly, lest he thinks he is wise.

verses.latin: Qui mittit verba per stultum, amputat pedes, et bibit iniquitatem.
verses.english: Whoever sends a message by a fool cuts off his own feet and drinks his own ruin.

verses.latin: Parabola in ore stultorum, quasi crura claudorum.
verses.english: A parable in the mouth of a fool is like the legs of a lame man.

verses.latin: Quasi qui mittit lapidem in acervum Mercurii, ita est qui dat honorem stulto.
verses.english: Whoever gives honor to a fool is like someone who ties a stone to a sling.

verses.latin: Spina in manu ebrii, sic parabola in ore stultorum.
verses.english: A thorn in the hand of a drunk is like a parable in the mouth of fools.

verses.latin: Magnus qui stultum facit omnia, et quasi dormiens, qui suscitat eum.
verses.english: The great God makes all things, and it is like a sleeping man who stirs him up.

verses.latin: Sicut canis revertitur ad vomitum suum, sic stultus revolvitur ad stultitiam suam.
verses.english: As a dog returns to its vomit, so the fool goes back to his foolishness.

verses.latin: Vidisti hominem sapientem sibi videri? Magis sperandum est de stulto, quam de eo.
verses.english: Have you seen a man wise in his own eyes? There is more hope for a fool than for him.

verses.latin: Dicit piger: Leo est in via, leo in plateis.
verses.english: The lazy man says, “There’s a lion in the road, a lion in the streets.”

verses.latin: Ostium vertitur super cardinem suum, et piger in lecto suo.
verses.english: The door turns on its hinges, and the lazy man on his bed.

verses.latin: Operit piger manum suam sub ascella, et laborat sustinere eam.
verses.english: The lazy man buries his hand in his armpit; he is exhausted from trying to hold it up.

verses.latin: Sapiens sibi videtur piger, plus quam potest enarrare.
verses.english: The lazy man is wiser in his own eyes than he can explain.

verses.latin: Quasi qui apprehendit aures canis, ita est qui irascens transit per alienam litem.
verses.english: Like someone who grabs a dog’s ears is the one who gets angry and interferes in someone else's quarrel.

verses.latin: Sicut insanus jacens jacula, et sagittas, et mortem,
verses.english: Like a madman shooting arrows, and deadly weapons,

verses.latin: sic vir qui laedit amicum, et postea dicit: Ludens, feci.
verses.english: is the man who deceives his friend and then says, “I was only joking.”

verses.latin: Deficiente ligno, exstinguitur ignis: et absente susurrone, quiescit contentio.
verses.english: When the wood runs out, the fire dies; and when the gossiper is gone, the quarrel dies down.

verses.latin: Sicut carbones ad prunas, et ligna ad ignem, sic homo iracundus ad excitandum rixam.
verses.english: Like coals for the embers and wood for the fire, so is a man of anger for kindling strife.

verses.latin: Verba susurronis quasi simplicia, et ipsa perveniunt ad interiora ventris.
verses.english: The words of a gossiper are like tasty morsels, but they go down into the innermost parts of the belly.

verses.latin: Labia dolosa, et cor malum: argentum conflatur in lebeto, et stercus super terram.
verses.english: Smooth lips and an evil heart are like a worthless pot covered with silver.

verses.latin: Qui odit, in labiis suis dissimulat, et in corde suo insidias disponit.
verses.english: The one who hates dissembles with his lips but harbors deceit in his heart.

verses.latin: Cum affaverit vox ejus, ne credideris ei: quia septem nequitiae in corde illius.
verses.english: When his voice is kind, don't trust him, because there are seven abominations in his heart.

verses.latin: Qui operit odium, arte celat: quod lateat in concilio, revelabitur.
verses.english: Though hatred is concealed by deception, its wickedness will be revealed in the assembly.

verses.latin: Qui fodit foveam, incidit in eam: et qui volvit lapidem, revertetur ad eum.
verses.english: Whoever digs a pit will fall into it, and whoever rolls a stone will have it roll back on him.

verses.latin: Lingua mendax odit eos quos contrivit: et os lubricum facit ruinas.
verses.english: A lying tongue hates those it wounds, and a flattering mouth causes ruin.

verses.latin: Ne glorieris in crastinum, ignorans quid superventura parturiat dies.
verses.english: Do not boast about tomorrow, because you do not know what a day will bring.

verses.latin: Laudet te alienus, et non os tuum: alienus, et non labia tua.
verses.english: Let another praise you, and not your own mouth; let a stranger, and not your own lips, do so.

verses.latin: Grave est saxum, et arena ponderosa: ira autem stulti, gravior utraque.
verses.english: A stone is heavy, and sand is weighty, but the anger of a fool is heavier than both.

verses.latin: Cruciatus ira, et furor, inundatio: et quis sustinebit spiritum iracundi?
verses.english: Wrath is cruel, and anger is overflowing, but who can stand before the spirit of a person who is angered?

verses.latin: Melius est manifestam arguentem, quam amicum dissimulantem.
verses.english: Better is open rebuke than hidden love.

verses.latin: Melior amicus, vulnerans, quam amicus dissimulans.
verses.english: Wounds from a friend are better than kisses from an enemy.

verses.latin: Anima saturata calcabit favum: et anima esuriens, etiam amarum pro dulci sumet.
verses.english: A satisfied soul will trample on the honeycomb, but to a hungry soul even the bitter is sweet.

verses.latin: Sicut avis volans e nido suo, sic vir qui egreditur de loco suo.
verses.english: Like a bird that wanders from its nest, so is a man who leaves his place.

verses.latin: Oleum et vas, laetificant cor: et consilium hominis amici dulcior.
verses.english: Oil and perfume rejoice the heart, and the advice of a friend is sweeter.

verses.latin: Amicum tuum, et amicum patris tui, ne dimiseris: et domum fratris tui ne intres in die afflictionis tuae. Melior est vicinus juxta, quam frater procul.
verses.english: Do not forsake your friend, or the friend of your father; and do not enter the house of your brother on the day of your calamity. Better is a neighbor nearby than a brother far away.

verses.latin: Filius meus, sapiens esto, et laetifica cor meum: ut possim exprobranti mihi respondere verbum.
verses.english: My son, be wise and gladden my heart, that I may have an answer for those who reproach me.

verses.latin: Callidus videns malum, cavit: parvuli, transierunt, et puniti sunt.
verses.english: A sensible man sees trouble and hides, but the simple pass on and suffer the consequences.

verses.latin: Sume vestimentum ejus qui spondet pro extraneo: et pro alieno, obtine pignus ab eo.
verses.english: Take the garment of one who puts up security for a stranger, and for an alien, hold him in pledge.

verses.latin: Qui benedicit proximo suo in magna voce, mane surgens, maledictioni comparabitur.
verses.english: He who blesses his neighbor with a loud voice, rising early in the morning, will be compared to a curse.

verses.latin: Stillicidia continua in die frigoris, et uxor contentiosa, comparantur.
verses.english: A continual dripping on a rainy day and a contentious woman are alike.

verses.latin: Qui celat eam, celat ventum: et oleum in dextera sua, vocabit.
verses.english: He who restrains her restrains the wind and grasps oil with his right hand.

verses.latin: Ferrum ferro, et homo exacuit faciem amici sui.
verses.english: Iron sharpens iron, and one man sharpens another.

verses.latin: Qui custodit ficum, comedet fructus ejus: et qui observat dominum suum, honorabitur.
verses.english: He who guards the fig tree will eat its fruit, and he who protects his master will be honored.

verses.latin: Quomodo in aquis resplendent vultus, ita corda hominum manifesta sunt prudentibus.
verses.english: As in water face answers to face, so the heart of man to man.

verses.latin: Infernum et perditio nunquam replentur: ita et oculi hominum nunquam satiantur.
verses.english: Sheol and destruction are never satisfied, nor are the eyes of man ever satisfied.

verses.latin: Quod probatur argento, et aurum in fornace: sic probat virum os laudantium.
verses.english: The crucible is for silver, and the furnace is for gold, and a man is tested by his praise.

verses.latin: Si contritis fueris stulto quasi triticum in pila, non auferetur de te stultitia ejus.
verses.english: Though you grind a fool in a mortar with a pestle along with the grain, his foolishness will not depart from him.

verses.latin: Diligenter nosces vultum pecoris tui: et geres corda tua.
verses.english: Know well the appearance of your flocks, and give attention to your herds.

verses.latin: Non est permanens divitiarum corona, in generationes: nec semper durabunt.
verses.english: For riches do not last forever; nor does a crown endure to all generations.

verses.latin: Cum apparuerit faenum, et ostensa fuerint herbae, et collectae fuerint fena de montibus.
verses.english: When the grass is gone, and the new growth appears, and the hay is gathered from the mountains,

verses.latin: Agni ad vestimenta tua, et caprarum pretium agris.
verses.english: the lambs will supply your clothing, and the goats the price of the field.

verses.latin: Sufficiat tibi lac caprarum ad cibos tuos, et ad alimenta domus tuae.
verses.english: There will be enough goats’ milk for your food, for the food of your household.

verses.latin: Impio fugiente, nemo persequitur: justi autem quasi leo confidens.
verses.english: When the wicked run away, no one chases them; the just have the boldness of a lion.

verses.latin: Pro delicto terrae multi principes ejus: propter hominem scientem, et prudentem, permanebit.
verses.english: When a land is in sin, it has many tyrants; with an intelligent leader, order will be kept.

verses.latin: Vir pauper opprimens pauperes, similis est imbre vehementi, in quo paratur fames.
verses.english: A poor man who oppresses the poor is like a rain that brings a famine.

verses.latin: Qui derelinquunt legem, laudant impium: qui custodiunt, incandescunt contra eum.
verses.english: Those who reject God's law praise the wicked; those who keep the law are always at odds with them.

verses.latin: Viri mali non cogitant judicium: qui autem quaerunt Dominum, intelligunt omnia.
verses.english: Evil men don't understand justice; those who seek the Lord understand everything.

verses.latin: Melior est pauper ambulans in simplicitate sua, quam dives in perversis viis.
verses.english: It is better to be poor and honest than rich and dishonest.

verses.latin: Qui custodit legem, filius sapiens: qui pascit nebulones, confundit patrem suum.
verses.english: Those who keep the law are wise children; those who feed the wicked shame their fathers.

verses.latin: Qui coacervat divitias suas usuris, et lucris, iniquus est contra proximum, et alterius in eis fruetur.
verses.english: Those who increase their wealth by usury or interest are unjust, and others will enjoy it.

verses.latin: Qui avertit aurem suam ne audiat legem, oratio ejus erit execrabilis.
verses.english: If you turn away from hearing the law, even your prayers are an abomination.

verses.latin: Qui seducit justos in via mala, in interitu suo corruet, et simplices possidebunt bona.
verses.english: Those who lead the upright down a wrong path will fall into their own traps, but the innocent will inherit good things.

verses.latin: Vir dives reputans se sapientem, stultus similis est, qui sperat in se.
verses.english: A rich man who considers himself wise is a fool, trusting in himself.

verses.latin: In exultatione justorum, magna gloria: cum autem creverint impii, abscondentur homines.
verses.english: When the just rejoice, there is great glory; when the wicked increase, men hide themselves.

verses.latin: Qui abscondit peccata sua, non dirigetur: qui confitetur et derelinquit ea, misericordiam consequetur.
verses.english: Those who hide their sins will not succeed; those who confess and abandon them will be shown mercy.

verses.latin: Beatus homo qui semper est pavidus: qui vero festinus ad divitias, non erit innocens.
verses.english: Blessed is the man who is always reverent; but he who rushes to get rich will not be without guilt.

verses.latin: Leo rugiens, et ursus esuriens, princeps impius super populum pauperem.
verses.english: Like a roaring lion or a hungry bear, so is a wicked ruler over a poor people.

verses.latin: Princeps indigens eloquio, multos opprimet: qui autem odiit avaritiam, longioris vitae erit.
verses.english: A leader who lacks understanding will oppress many; but he who hates greed will live a long time.

verses.latin: Homo qui calumniatur sanguinem animae, festinabit ad lacum: non prohibeatur ei.
verses.english: A man burdened by the guilt of murder will be haunted by it; let no one help him.

verses.latin: Qui ambulat simpliciter, salvus erit: qui perversis viis incedit, corruet semel.
verses.english: Those who walk uprightly will be saved; those who go the wrong way will fall.

verses.latin: Qui operatur terram suam, saturabitur panibus: qui sectatur otiosos, saturabitur mendaciis.
verses.english: Those who work their land will have plenty of food; those who chase empty dreams will be full of lies.

verses.latin: Vir fidelis multum laudabitur: qui autem festinat ditari, non erit innocens.
verses.english: A faithful man will be greatly praised; but he who rushes to get rich will not be innocent.

verses.latin: Qui iniquitatem respicit in judicio, non bonus est: propter frustrum panis, vir talis vendet veritatem.
verses.english: It's wrong to show partiality in judgment; even for a piece of bread, such a man will betray the truth.

verses.latin: Vir nequam festinans ad divitias, et qui non est innocens, non erit impunitus.
verses.english: A wicked man who rushes to get rich, and is not innocent, will not go unpunished.

verses.latin: Qui arguit hominem, postea inveniet gratiam, magis quam ille qui linguam adulationis habet.
verses.english: He who rebukes a man will later find more favor than he who has a flattering tongue.

verses.latin: Qui furatur a patre suo, et a matre, et dicit: Non est peccatum: socius est homicidae.
verses.english: He who robs his father or his mother, and says, “It’s not wrong,” is a companion to a murderer.

verses.latin: Qui jactat animam, suscitat lites: qui confisus est in Domino, impinguabitur.
verses.english: A greedy man stirs up conflict; those who trust in the Lord will prosper.

verses.latin: Qui confidet in corde suo, stultus est: qui autem graditur in sapientia, ipse salvabitur.
verses.english: Those who trust in their own hearts are fools; those who walk in wisdom will be saved.

verses.latin: Qui dat pauperi, non indigebit: qui calumnias avertit oculos suos, habundabit.
verses.english: Those who give to the poor will not want; those who turn away their eyes from the poor will be blessed.

verses.latin: In impiis cum surrexerint, abscondentur homines: et cum perierint, multiplicabuntur justi.
verses.english: When the wicked rise, men hide; when the wicked perish, the upright will increase.

verses.latin: Qui corripit colendum, odibilis erit, qui arguit impium, ipse sibi notam inducit.
verses.english: If you rebuke someone you want to be respected, you will be hated. If you correct the wicked, you will get in trouble.

verses.latin: Qui diligit sapientiam, laetificat patrem suum: qui autem pascit scortas, perdet substantiam.
verses.english: If you love wisdom, you will make your father happy, but if you spend your time with prostitutes, you will waste your wealth.

verses.latin: Vir justus per judicium dirigit proximum suum: impius vero viam suam sectatur.
verses.english: If you want to be just, you will bring your neighbor before God's judgement. Wicked people will always follow their own path.

verses.latin: Vir mendax opera iniquitatis dat oculos: vir autem justus scientiam ponit.
verses.english: Liars destroy society; the just value knowledge.

verses.latin: Vir stultus contemnit disciplinam patris sui: qui autem sequitur correptiones, prudentior erit.
verses.english: A fool scorns his father's teaching. Those who welcome correction become wiser.

verses.latin: Justus, aequitate sua, liberabit proximum suum: impius autem in rapina implicabitur.
verses.english: The righteous become free through the judgment of the world; the wicked are always trapped by their own greed.

verses.latin: Vir sapiens custodit animam suam: stultus et timidus non sustinebit.
verses.english: A wise man protects his soul. A fool and a coward cannot stand up for themselves.

verses.latin: Vir justus novit causam pauperum: impius ignorat scientiam.
verses.english: The just know how to care for the poor. The wicked do not value knowledge.

verses.latin: Homines pestilentes conturbant civitatem: sapientes vero mitem iram componunt.
verses.english: When the wicked stir up chaos, they destroy a city, but the wise will bring peace.

verses.latin: Vir sapiens, si cum stulto egerit, sive irascatur, sive rideat, non inveniet requiem.
verses.english: The wise, if they deal with a fool, will find no rest, whether they are angry or laughing.

verses.latin: Viri sanguinum oderunt innocentem: justi autem quaerunt animam ejus.
verses.english: Murderers hate the innocent. The righteous seek to save their lives.

verses.latin: Omnis stultus statim irascitur: qui differt, facile vincit.
verses.english: A fool immediately becomes angry, but those who hold back easily win.

verses.latin: Princeps qui judicat pauperes in veritate, thronus ejus in aeternum stabilis erit.
verses.english: A prince who judges the poor honestly, his throne will be made stable forever.

verses.latin: Vir flagitiosus laqueum jacit amico suo: justus vero salvus erit, et sine cura.
verses.english: If someone is wicked, they set a trap for their friend, but the just will be delivered from evil and have nothing to fear.

verses.latin: Impius in sua nequitia impeditur: justus sperat in conscientia sua.
verses.english: The wicked are trapped by their own wickedness, but the righteous find hope in their conscience.

verses.latin: Vir sapiens in judiciis, qui odit avaritiam, longus erit in diebus.
verses.english: The wise man, in his actions, will avoid greed. He will live a long life.

verses.latin: Vir qui calumniatur sanguinem animae, festinabit ad profundum: non sibi parcet.
verses.english: A man who is a murderer, they will always be in the deepest and darkest part of their soul, they will never be at peace.

verses.latin: Qui ambulat simpliciter, salvus erit: qui perversus est in viis suis, cito corruet.
verses.english: If you are sincere, you will be safe. If you are dishonest, you will quickly fall.

verses.latin: Qui operatur terram suam, saturabitur panibus: qui sectatur otiosos, saturabitur egestate.
verses.english: If you work your land, you will have plenty of food, but if you follow idle people, you will be poor.

verses.latin: Vir fidelis multum laudabitur: qui autem festinat ditari, non erit innocens.
verses.english: A faithful man will be greatly praised, but if you are eager to get rich, you will not be innocent.

verses.latin: Qui iniquus est in judicio, odit homines: qui autem oderat causam, perdet animam suam.
verses.english: If you are unjust in judgement, you hate men. If you hate a just cause, you will lose your soul.

verses.latin: Qui confidet in corde suo, stultus est: qui autem ingreditur in sapientia, hic salvabitur.
verses.english: If you trust in your own heart, you are a fool, but those who walk with wisdom, will be saved.
