verses.latin: Qui arguit hominem, gratiam postea inveniet magis quam ille qui lingua adulatur.
verses.english: If you correct a man, you will find favor more than if you use flattery.

verses.latin: Qui furatur patrem suum, vel matrem, et dicit: Non peccavi, hic socius est homicidae.
verses.english: If you steal from your father or mother and say, "I have not sinned," you are a companion to a murderer.

verses.latin: Qui dilatat gulam, provocat jurgium: qui autem confidit in Domino, saginabitur.
verses.english: If you are greedy, you stir up conflict, but those who trust in the Lord will be satisfied.

verses.latin: Qui confidet in corde suo, stultus est: qui vero ambulat in sapientia, hic salvus erit.
verses.english: If you trust your own heart, you are a fool. If you walk with wisdom, you will be saved.

verses.latin: Qui dat pauperi, non indigebit: qui calumnias avertit oculos suos, habundabit benedictionibus.
verses.english: If you give to the poor, you will not be in need. If you turn away from evil, you will be blessed.

verses.latin: Cum impii creverint, multiplicabuntur iniquitates: et justi videbunt corruentem.
verses.english: When the wicked rise, iniquity increases, but the righteous will see them fall.

verses.latin: Vir qui contemnit doctrinam, odibilis est: qui autem observat mandata, salvabitur.
verses.english: A man who despises discipline is hated, but those who obey the commandments will be saved.

verses.latin: Cum dominantur impii, gemiscet populus: cumperit justi, gaudebunt homines.
verses.english: When the wicked rule, the people groan, but when the just perish, people rejoice.

verses.latin: Qui diligit sapientiam, laetificat patrem suum: qui autem pascit scortas, perdet substantiam.
verses.english: If you love wisdom, you will make your father happy, but if you spend your time with prostitutes, you will waste your wealth.

verses.latin: Verba Aggur filii Iace, visio. Vir dixit: Cum quo sum, Deus? cum quo sum et non quiesco?
verses.english: These are the words of Agur, son of Iace, a vision. The man said, “With whom am I, God? With whom am I, and I do not rest?”

verses.latin: Quia stultior sum omnibus hominibus, et sapientia hominum non est mecum.
verses.english: For I am more foolish than all men, and the wisdom of men is not with me.

verses.latin: Nescio sapientiam, et scientiam sanctorum ignoro.
verses.english: I do not know wisdom, and I do not know the knowledge of the holy ones.

verses.latin: Quis ascendit in cælum, et descendit? Quis continuit spiritum manibus suis? Quis colligavit aquas quasi in vestimento? Quis statuit omnes terminos terræ? Quod nomen ejus, et quod nomen filii ejus, si nosti?
verses.english: Who has ascended into the sky and descended? Who has held the wind in his hands? Who has gathered the waters as if in a garment? Who has established all the boundaries of the earth? What is His name, and what is the name of His Son, if you know?

verses.latin: Omnis sermo Dei ignitus; scutum est sperantibus in se.
verses.english: Every word of God is tested by fire; He is the shield to those who hope in Him.

verses.latin: Ne addas quidquam verbis illius, ne arguaris, et inveniaris mendax.
verses.english: Do not add anything to His words, lest you be reproved, and found to be a liar.

verses.latin: Duo rogavi te; ne deneges mihi antequam moriar.
verses.english: I have asked two things of you; do not deny them to me before I die:

verses.latin: Vanitatem et verba mendacia longe fac a me; divitias et paupertatem ne dederis mihi: sed tribue mihi necessaria vitæ meæ:
verses.english: Remove vanity and lying words far from me; give me neither riches nor poverty: but supply me with the necessities of my life:

verses.latin: ne forte saturatus, neget, et dicat: Quis est Dominus? aut egestate coactus, furer, et perjurans nomen Dei mei.
verses.english: Lest perhaps, being filled, I should deny, and say: Who is the Lord? Or being forced by poverty, I should steal, and take the name of my God in vain.

verses.latin: Ne accuses servum ad dominum suum, ne forte maledictus te, et poenas luas.
verses.english: Do not accuse a servant to his master, lest perhaps he curse you, and you pay the penalty.

verses.latin: Est generatio quæ patrem suum maledicit, et matrem suam non benedicit.
verses.english: There is a generation that curses their father, and does not bless their mother.

verses.latin: Generatio quæ sibi munda videtur, et tamen non est lota a sordibus suis.
verses.english: A generation that seems clean to itself, but is not washed from its filth.

verses.latin: Generatio! Quorum oculo elati sunt, et palpebris suis extolluntur.
verses.english: A generation whose eyes are lifted up, and are puffed up with their eyelids.

verses.latin: Generatio! Quorum dentes gladii, et molares eorum ad comedendum pauperes de terra, et inopes ex hominibus.
verses.english: A generation whose teeth are like swords, and their molars to devour the poor from the earth, and the needy from among men.

verses.latin: Sanguisugæ duæ filiæ sunt, dicentes: Affer, affer. Tria sunt quæ nunquam saturantur: et quartum quod nunquam dicit: Sufficit.
verses.english: The leech has two daughters, saying: Bring, bring. There are three things that are never satisfied: and a fourth that never says: It is enough.

verses.latin: Infernus, et vulvæ, et terra quæ non satiatur aqua; et ignis qui nunquam dicit: Sufficit.
verses.english: Hell, and the womb, and the earth that is not satisfied with water; and the fire that never says: It is enough.

verses.latin: Oculus qui subsannat patrem, et qui despicit ad obedire matrem, effodiant eum corvi de torrentibus, et comedant eum filii aquilæ.
verses.english: The eye that mocks his father, and despises to obey his mother, let the ravens of the brooks dig it out, and the eagles' sons eat it.

verses.latin: Tria sunt quæ mihi mira videntur, et quartum quod penitus ignoro:
verses.english: There are three things that seem wonderful to me, and a fourth that I completely do not know:

verses.latin: Viam aquilæ in cælo, viam colubri super petram, viam navis in mari, et viam viri in adolescentia.
verses.english: The way of the eagle in the sky, the way of the serpent upon a rock, the way of a ship in the sea, and the way of a man in youth.

verses.latin: Talem viam adulteræ: quæ comedit, et tergens os suum, dicit se operata non esse malum.
verses.english: Such is the way of the adulteress: she eats, and wiping her mouth, says that she has done no evil.

verses.latin: Per tria movetur terra, et quartum quod non potest sustinere:
verses.english: Under three things the earth trembles, and under a fourth it cannot stand:

verses.latin: Sub servo cum regnaverit; et stulto cum saturatus fuerit cibo:
verses.english: Under a servant when he reigns; and a fool when he is filled with food:

verses.latin: Sub odiosa quando nupserit; et ancilla cum fuerit hæres dominæ suæ.
verses.english: Under a hateful woman when she is married; and a handmaid when she is the heir of her mistress.

verses.latin: Quatuor sunt minima terræ, et hæc sunt sapientiora sapientibus.
verses.english: There are four things that are the smallest on earth, and these are wiser than the wise:

verses.latin: Formicæ, plebs infirma, quæ præparant in messe cibum sibi.
verses.english: The ants, a weak people, which prepare their food in the harvest.

verses.latin: Cuniculi, plebs invalida, quæ ponunt in petra domum suam.
verses.english: The rabbits, a weak people, which place their house in a rock.

verses.latin: Locustæ non habentes regem, et egrediuntur universi per turmas suas.
verses.english: The locusts have no king, and they all go out in their bands.

verses.latin: Lacerta manibus nitens, et morans in palatiis regum.
verses.english: The lizard that relies on its hands, and dwells in the palaces of kings.

verses.latin: Tria sunt quæ bene gradiuntur, et quartum quod gressus suos benè dirigit.
verses.english: There are three things that walk well, and a fourth that directs its steps well:

verses.latin: Leo fortissimus in bestiis, et coram nullo pavebit.
verses.english: The lion, the strongest among beasts, and will not be afraid before any.

verses.latin: Gallina quæ graditur audacter inter animalia; et equus insignis ad prælium.
verses.english: The rooster that walks boldly among animals; and a horse prepared for battle.

verses.latin: Et rex, cui non est qui resistat in contumeliis ejus.
verses.english: And the king, to whom there is no one who resists in his insults.

verses.latin: Si stulte egisti, elevatus in facto, conprime manum: et si senseris mala, comprimere os tuum.
verses.english: If you have acted foolishly, being lifted up in the act, press your hand: and if you have perceived evil, compress your mouth.

verses.latin: Qui enim premit ubera, ut eliciat lac, butyrum provocat. Et qui vehementer urget nares, elicit sanguinem: et qui durius provocat iram, producit discordiam.
verses.english: For he who presses the breast, to draw out milk, provokes butter. And he who vehemently presses the nostrils, draws out blood: and he who more harshly provokes anger, produces discord.

verses.latin: Verba Lemuelis regis. Professio qua erudivit eum mater sua.
verses.english: These are the words of King Lemuel. His mother taught him these truths.

verses.latin: Quid, fili mi, quid, fili uteri mei, quid, fili votorum meorum?
verses.english: What, my son? What, son of my womb? What, son of my vows?

verses.latin: Ne tradas in potentibus vires tuas, et viam tuam his qui moliuntur reges.
verses.english: Do not give your strength to powerful men, nor your ways to those who harm kings.

verses.latin: Ne regibus, o Lemuel, ne regibus vinum, et ubi est potestas, ne spiritus ebrietatis:
verses.english: It is not for kings, Lemuel, not for kings to drink wine, nor to desire strong drink.

verses.latin: ne forte bibant et obliviscantur judicia, et mutent causam filiorum pauperis.
verses.english: Lest, while drinking, they forget what is right and change the law to hurt the poor.

verses.latin: Date siceram pereunti, et vinum his qui amaro sunt animo:
verses.english: Give strong drink to those who are lost, and wine to those who are in bitterness of soul.

verses.latin: ut bibant et obliviscantur paupertatis suae, et ne meminerint molestiae suae amplius.
verses.english: Let them drink and forget their poverty, and no longer remember their suffering.

verses.latin: Aperire os tuum muto, et causas eorum qui pertransierunt.
verses.english: Open your mouth for the mute, and for the causes of those who are in need.

verses.latin: Aperire os tuum, judica quod justum est, et fac judicium pauperis et egeno.
verses.english: Open your mouth, judge what is just, and act with judgment for the poor and the needy.

verses.latin: Mulierem fortem quis inveniet? Procul et de ultimis finibus pretium ejus.
verses.english: Who will find a brave woman? She is more valuable than all of the world's treasures.

verses.latin: Confidit in ea cor viri sui, et spoliis non indigebit.
verses.english: Her husband's heart trusts in her, and he will have no lack of gains.

verses.latin: Reddet illi bonum, et non malum, omnibus diebus vitae suae.
verses.english: She does him good, and not evil, all the days of her life.

verses.latin: Quæsivit lanam et linum, et operata est industriosa manibus suis.
verses.english: She seeks wool and flax, and works willingly with her hands.

verses.latin: Facta est quasi navis institoris: de longe conportat panem suum.
verses.english: She is like the merchant ships: she brings her food from afar.

verses.latin: Et de nocte surrexit, deditque praedam domui suae, et cibaria ancillis suis.
verses.english: She rises while it is still night, and gives food to her household, and a portion to her maidservants.

verses.latin: Consideravit agrum, et emit eum: de fructu manuum suarum plantavit vineam.
verses.english: She considers a field, and buys it: with the fruit of her hands she plants a vineyard.

verses.latin: Accinxit fortitudine lumbos suos, et roboravit brachia sua.
verses.english: She girds her loins with strength, and strengthens her arms.

verses.latin: Vidit quod bona esset negotiatio ejus: non extinguitur in nocte lucerna ejus.
verses.english: She sees that her work is good: her lamp is not extinguished at night.

verses.latin: Manum suam misit ad fortia, et palmi ejus confirmaverunt telas.
verses.english: She puts her hand to strong tasks, and her palms have confirmed the threads.

verses.latin: Pauperi manum aperuit, et palmas suas extendit in egeno.
verses.english: She opens her hand to the poor, and extends her palms to the needy.

verses.latin: Non timebit domum suam a frigore nivis: omnes enim domestici ejus vestiti sunt duplicibus.
verses.english: She will not fear for her household because of the snow: for all her household are clothed in double garments.

verses.latin: Stramenta fecit sibi, et purpura est vestimentum ejus.
verses.english: She makes coverings for herself, and her clothing is fine linen and purple.

verses.latin: Cognitus in portis vir ejus, quando sederit cum senibus terrae.
verses.english: Her husband is known at the gates, when he sits with the elders of the land.

verses.latin: Lineas fecit, et vendidit, et cingulum tradidit Chananeo.
verses.english: She makes linen and sells it, and gives a girdle to the merchant.

verses.latin: Fortitudo et decor indumentum ejus: et ridebit in die novissimo.
verses.english: Strength and beauty are her clothing: and she will laugh in the last day.

verses.latin: Os suum aperuit sapientiæ, et lex clementiæ in lingua ejus.
verses.english: She opens her mouth with wisdom, and the law of kindness is on her tongue.

verses.latin: Considerat gressus domus suae, et panem otiosa non comedit.
verses.english: She considers the ways of her household, and does not eat the bread of idleness.

verses.latin: Surrexerunt filii ejus, et beatissimam dixerunt; vir ejus, et laudavit eam.
verses.english: Her children rise up, and call her blessed; her husband also, and he praises her.

verses.latin: Multi filiæ collegerunt divitias: tu supergressa es universas.
verses.english: Many daughters have gathered riches: but you surpass them all.

verses.latin: Fallax gratia, et vana est pulchritudo: mulier timens Deum ipsa laudabitur.
verses.english: Charm is deceitful, and beauty is vain: but a woman who fears God will be praised.

verses.latin: Date ei de fructu manuum suarum: et laudent eam in portis opera ejus.
verses.english: Give her of the fruit of her hands: and let her works praise her in the gates.
